All the factors of agronomy are so much dependent on rainfall in India, where unpredictability of monsoon and uneven distribution of rainfall leaves us with the next best option - Irrigation! The key aspect of this paper is to select best suitable solutions from the major irrigation systems namely drip irrigation, surface irrigation, sprinkler irrigation and sub-surface irrigation. Machine learning comes to rescue as the model is trained with thousands of samples of data along with the best irrigation system suitable for respective location. The location of a farm or field is selected using illustrator nominator wherein appropriate crop recommendation report can be generated to improve the productivity using machine learning algorithms. Thus, machine learning is on its way to help the farmers to adapt suitable system according to their requirements.

Document Title: Advancing Farming Practices: Machine Learning Algorithms for Optimal Crop Selection
Authors: S. Bhatnagar; A. Chadalawada

Abstract: This study underscores the critical importance of the agricultural sector for ensuring global food security and economic resilience, emphasizing the role of machine learning (ML)-enhanced crop recommendation systems. These systems are increasingly crucial for guiding farmers in choosing crops that are best suited to their unique soil and environmental conditions. Through the analysis of a comprehensive dataset, including soil composition, climate variations, historical crop yields, and agricultural practices, this research evaluates the performance of several ML algorithms–such as neural networks, decision trees, random forests, and support vector machines–in forecasting the most appropriate crops. Training on historical data allows these algorithms to decipher the complex dynamics between environmental factors and crop results. The success of these models is gauged by metrics including accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. This study also delves into the models' interpretability, offering crucial insights to both agricultural practitioners and researchers. Moreover, it presents the creation of a user-friendly web application that applies these ML models to provide personalized crop recommendations, requiring user inputs like geographical location, soil characteristics, and weather data. The findings reveal that ML algorithms can significantly empower farmers with knowledge to select suitable crops, thereby boosting agricultural efficiency, optimizing the use of resources, and enhancing the sustainability of agricultural operations. The research highlights the necessity of selecting the right ML algorithms and preprocessing techniques for achieving superior results. Notably, we have enhanced the accuracy of the random forest algorithm to 99.92% and ADABOOST with the Decision Tree Classifier to 99.02%. This contribution to precision agriculture showcases the practical use of ML in crop recommendation systems as a technological approach to addressing agricultural sector challenges and bolstering the global food supply chain.

Authors: S. Vats; V. Kukreja; S. Mehta
Author Affiliations: Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India
Publication Title: 2024 IEEE International Conference on Interdisciplinary Approaches in Technology and Management for Social Innovation (IATMSI)
Abstract: Jute is important to the textile and agricultural industries, especially in Asia. This study uses a unique method that combines Federated Learning (FL) and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) to detect and classify five important groups of jute leaf diseases. Using data from five different customers, each representing a separate collection of data for every illness class, the research demonstrates the flexibility and power of FL in protecting data sovereignty while gaining access to insights from across the world. A comprehensive review of the results shows excellent illness categorization skills. In particular, the following averages were discovered for the customers Lj_1 through Lj_5: Lj_1 displayed weighted, macro, and standards of 82.98%, 81.45%, and 83.04%; Lj_2 showed 86.71%, 86.66%, and 86.17%; Lj_3 showed 86.17%, 86.82%, and 86.84%; Lj_4 showed 91.70%, 91.71%, and 91.39%; and Lj_5 showed 87.09%, 88.09%, and 88.07%. These measures show the model's proficiency and the subtle differences in customer performance. This study explores federated averaging methods and focuses on macro, micro, and weighted averages. Weighted averages consider differences in class distribution, micro averages provide a comprehensive system performance, and macro standards treat each disease class equally. In conclusion, the study fills a gap in the market by combining the deep learning capabilities of CNNs with the decentralization advantages of Federated Learning, providing a strong answer to the complex problem of jute leaf diseases. The study's contributions to smart agriculture are solidified by the experimental and statistical values offered, serving as a guide for further research in the field.

Agricultural robots (agrobots) hold great promise in addressing the aforementioned challenges. Starting from ideas at the basis of our project at POLIMI on fruit farming, this paper presents a context study, and a knowledgebased approach to model smart agricultural environments, where farms use sensors and agrobots, and cooperate via Digital Twins towards the execution of complex tasks. This assessment is crucial in determining the most strategic approach to developing and enhancing these systems, enabling researchers to achieve a certain degree of systemic optimization. Integrating IoT is one of the main benefits of this study, with the following information further highlighting the main application in agricultural sector: In the field of agriculture, the integration of Internet of Things such as sensors can reduce the need for manual labor and maximize efficiency in farms. Then, the collected information can be distributed to related devices for decision-making and resource management. This could lead to improved agricultural productivity. Author Affiliations: Department of Telecommunications, University Politehnica of Bucharest (UPB), Bucharest, Romania; Department of Telecommunications, University Politehnica of Bucharest (UPB), Bucharest, Romania; Department of Telecommunications, University Politehnica of Bucharest (UPB), Bucharest, Romania
Publication Title: 2022 25th International Symposium on Wireless Personal Multimedia Communications (WPMC)
Abstract: LoRaWAN-enabled networks represent a paradigm shift from short-range transmissions to long-range connections for various intelligent Internet of Things (IoT) applications. To ensure maximum coverage of LoRaWAN gateways, exhaustive experiments have to be performed beforehand for gateway deployment. Although simulation based solutions are viable, the obtained results may not reflect on-field propagation and terrain conditions. On the other hand, commercial LoRaWAN network field testers are extremely limited in terms of analysis and statistics capabilities. In this paper, we present an end-to-end IoT platform which encompasses an built-in network coverage testing facility. The term built-in is used to reveal coverage testing is an in-built functionality. That is, it is not necessary to use an external solution to test the coverage of the LoRaWan network, but the platform provides it by design. The platform is developed based on open-source software and commercial low-cost, low-power hardware, and it can be applied to various vertical sectors including smart agriculture, maritime applications, environment monitoring, and device tracking.

Abstract: The presence of rice spot disease presents a substantial risk to the overall production of rice worldwide, which highlights the need for an effective and precise evaluation of disease severity in order to implement prompt interventions. This study introduces a new methodology that utilizes machine learning algorithms, notably Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Random Forest (RF), for the automated categorization of severity levels in rice spot disease. A curated dataset consisting of 9,000 high-resolution photos of rice plants was compiled, including a wide range of disease severity levels, ranging from healthy plants to those badly affected by diseases. The hybrid model, which combines elements of CNN and RF, demonstrated exceptional performance with an overall accuracy of 95.49%. This surpasses the accuracy achieved by the separate CNN and RF models. The integration of deep learning with ensemble learning presents a resilient approach for the timely identification of diseases and the accurate management of crops. The comparative study reveals that the hybrid model exhibits greater performance, whereas the feature importance analysis provides insights into the crucial visual qualities that inform future research. This study signifies a crucial advancement in the field of precision agriculture, as it facilitates the ability to make well-informed decisions that protect crop yields and improve global food security.

Authors: K. D. Dey; T. R. Sudhini; A. Burli; V. G. N

Publication Title: 2024 International Conference on Emerging Research in Computational Science (ICERCS)
Abstract: As the demand for global food rising, the need for sustainable farming practices becomes more urgent, and the accurate assessment of crop quality becomes increasingly critical. Traditional methods of crop evaluation are labor-intensive, time-consuming, and susceptible to human error, leading to inconsistent results that adversely affect agricultural productivity. This work develops an automated crop quality assessment system utilizing computer vision and deep learning techniques to enhance the efficiency and accuracy of crop evaluations. The primary purpose of this system is to provide farmers, vendors, and retailers with reliable tools for assessing crop quality, facilitating informed decision-making, and reducing waste. By classifying crops into three categories— Good, Medium, and Bad—the system supports better market efficiency and promotes eco-friendly agricultural practices. This work employs Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), specifically leveraging pre-trained models such as VGG16 and EfficientNetB0 for feature extraction and classification. The methodology involves collecting a diverse dataset of crop images under varying environmental conditions, followed by data augmentation to simulate real-world variations and improve model generalization. The system is designed with a user-friendly interface that allows stakeholders to upload images and receive immediate quality assessments. The results demonstrate high accuracy, validated through precision, recall, and confusion matrix analysis. Ultimately, this work transforms traditional crop assessment methods, empowering stakeholders with advanced technological solutions for improved agricultural management.

Authors: R. Pillai; N. Sharma; R. Chauhan; D. Rawat; R. Gupta
Author Affiliations: Chitkara University Institute of Engineering & Technology Chitkara University Punjab, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering & Technology Chitkara University Punjab, India; Computer Science & Engineering Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, India; Computer Science & Engineering Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering & Technology Chitkara University Punjab, India

Abstract: Due to its importance as a worldwide staple crop, rice is crucial in guaranteeing the food security of billions of people. Due to a broad range of rice varieties, each of which has specific properties and characteristics, accurate categorization of rice variations is essential for agricultural practices, commerce, and culinary uses. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) are an excellent option for tackling the difficulties of rice variety categorization since they have become a potent deep-learning technique. A CNN model for the precise and efficient categorization of rice types is presented in this study. An extensive set of 75,000 images from five different types of rice (Arborio, Basmati, Ipsala, Jasmine, and Karacadag) was assembled for model training and assessment. To facilitate unbiased performance measurement, the dataset was partitioned at random into a training batch of 60,000 images and a test batch of 15,000 images. CNNs can learn hierarchical representations of visual input, allowing them to recognize complex patterns and connections within images, making them ideally suited for computer vision applications, notably image classification. This skill is essential for classifying rice varieties since it allows for detecting minute variations across rice kinds. The research's findings are encouraging because the proposed CNN model had a remarkable accuracy on the test set of 97.31%. This high degree of precision supports the model's outstanding capacity to distinguish between the five annotated classes of rice varieties, demonstrating the promise of deep learning methods in solving complex agricultural problems. The efficacy of this CNN-based strategy will significantly impact the agriculture industry. Accurate rice variety identification gives farmers the flexibility to modify growing techniques per particular needs while maintaining the purity and legitimacy of the final product for the food business.

Abstract: The prevalence of grape leaf diseases has had a profound influence on the worldwide grape industry, resulting in considerable financial setbacks. For effective disease management, it is essential to classify the disease quickly and accurately. This research presents an enhanced YOLOv7 deep-learning model for accurately classifying grape leaf diseases. The dataset is obtained from Kaggle and consists of four categories: black rot, leaf blight, black measles, and healthy. The Adam optimizer is utilized to optimize hyperparameters in order to enhance the performance of the model. The refined YOLOv7 model achieved a remarkable accuracy of 99.24% on the test set, showcasing its potential for detecting grape leaf diseases at an early stage. The model in precision agriculture can aid in the management of grape production, categorization of leaf diseases, and monitoring of operations.

For each disease category, the model can correctly classify a positive case with precision values ranging from 92.45% to 93.75%. Support Proportions indicate how much of the overall dataset can be attributed to a given disease class and Support Values show where there are occurrences in each proportion. Its great Weighted Average Accuracy of 93.25% shows that the model is trained on a wide range of plant diseases so it does not only work for one or two datasets but across all datasets. This endto-end macro-average and micro-average evaluation, again only shows all around effectiveness of the model. Results & conclusions: This study provides a highly accurate automated plant disease diagnostic model, which is of great significance for crop management and precision agriculture. Abstract: The development of agriculture is based on the improvement of living standards, at the national level in the provinces of Cotopaxi and Tungurahua represents a topic of special interest, currently the agricultural sector is impacted by climate change, temperature and humidity variation, and soil alteration. This is why the Internet of Things with the integration of wireless communication technologies and sensors offer the possibility of generating technological systems that collect data from crop fields. The present study was based on the comparative analysis of wireless communication technologies for IoT in the monitoring of agricultural areas, compiling studies of scientific databases identifying global, American continent and local trends. The communication technologies were evaluated with their characteristics based on the Hierarchical Analysis Process method, obtaining Sigfox, LoRa and Zigbee as the main alternatives for radio coverage simulations. Subsequently, the radiation pattern of the technologies was obtained, selecting Sigfox for its characteristics and performance as the technology to be implemented for the network and sensor node operation. It was concluded that Sigfox is suitable for monitoring agricultural crops due to its wide coverage range, economic cost and low data sending rate, being a communication alternative for early warning of frost detection.

Abstract: Crop pests pose a great threat to global food security; thus, the best pest prevention measures must be implemented. By using different machine learning (ML) techniques to perform crop pest classification, this research provides ways to improve the accuracy and speed of identifying pests in agricultural sectors. Conventional methods for identifying pests frequently depend on manual observation, which is tedious, error-prone, and labor-intensive. On the other hand, machine learning (ML) presents an effective way to automate this procedure by using sophisticated techniques to analyze massive data sets and produce precise predictions. The study applies a variety of machine learning approaches, such as Random Forests, K-Nearest Neighbor, and Naive Bayes, to classify agricultural pests according to features that have been extracted from images. For model training and validation, an extensive collection of high-resolution images of different agricultural pests taken in a range of environmental settings is used. Metrics like accuracy are used to determine how well the machine learning models perform. The potential of machine learning approaches to revolutionize pest management in agriculture is evident from the results, which indicate how accurately they can identify and classify agricultural pests. The suggested method improves the overall effectiveness of pest management procedures and drastically reduces the time and effort required to identify pests. Ultimately, this research promotes more resilient and productive farming systems by supporting efforts to develop sustainable and technologically advanced solutions for addressing agricultural difficulties. The results demonstrate the potential of machine learning (ML) as an invaluable tool for farmers, agronomists, and policymakers, encouraging a proactive and data-driven approach to pest management in contemporary agriculture.

Authors: K. Quintanilla-Castro; R. Meza-Molina; Y. Rodriguez-Gallo; M. Cardona; J. Cruz

Publication Title: 2024 IEEE International Conference on Machine Learning and Applied Network Technologies (ICMLANT)
Abstract: The Coffee Berry Borer (CBB), Hypothenemus hampei, is one of the most serious threats to global coffee production. This study provides a thorough analysis of the different types of traps used for detecting and controlling the CBB, outlines the development of a preliminary electronic device capable of capturing images of the pest in coffee plantations, and details the creation of a dedicated database. Through a systematic literature review of 13 relevant studies, we examined various trap designs and attractant combinations used for CBB detection. Additionally, we developed a prototype device equipped with an ESP32-CAM microcontroller and solar power capability for continuous field monitoring. The device captures high-resolution images at 15-minute intervals. A preliminary database of 500 images was created. Our findings suggest that effective trap placement typically ranges from 1.2 to 1.5 meters above ground, with a 3:1 methanol-ethanol mixture serving as the optimal attractant. This research contributes to the development of automated CBB monitoring systems and establishes a foundation for future applications of artificial intelligence (AI) in pest management strategies.

Abstract: Tea blister disease caused by Exobasidium vexans, a deceitful and devastating pathogen is one of the greatest threats to the tea industry across global. We need more sophisticated assessment instruments to enable us to fight it much better, faster, and more efficiently. This research is a major change. This approach uses Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and K-nearest neighbors (KNN) to enable easy integration of deep learning (DL) methods. 43,000 photos representing different diseases affecting tea plants are carefully arranged to form the basis of our most intelligent ideas. The proposed integrated model has been rigorously tested and assessed with a sufficiently large sample size showing an outstanding overall accuracy rate of 99.27%. It is excellent in understanding the driving forces behind a tea boiling situation's potential to worsen or lead to different levels of blister damage that an individual might face, influenced by health disparities. In addition to the correctness, a complete analysis should also include the concepts of precision-recall and F1 score. On the one hand, our algorithm can classify items in a way not only to categorize them but also to understand many other nuances that could associate themselves with different blisters. In this demonstration of the uses of DL, we see how it can adapt and understand much more complicated nuances even in cases that involve a different degree. When comparing our method to basic models such as single-training CNN and KNN, a mixed approach is shown to be a strong choice for various modes of operation. Our model performs better than others because of its high accuracy and ability to correctly detect complex changes in the forms of different kinds of lesions.

Geo-IoT data can be used in various IoT applications for optimizing routes, tracking assets, real-time traffic notification, auto-driving, precision agriculture, anti-theft prevention, etc. This paper provides a review of the convergence of Geo-IoT with advanced technologies such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, and blockchain technology. Authors: H. Li; N. Li; W. Wang; C. Yang; N. Chen; F. Deng
Author Affiliations: School of Computer Science and Engineering, Macau University of Science and Technology, Macau, China; School of Computer Science and Engineering, Macau University of Science and Technology, Macau, China; School of Computer Science and Engineering, Macau University of Science and Technology, Macau, China; School of Computer Science and Engineering, Macau University of Science and Technology, Macau, China; College of Information Science and Technology, Zhongkai University of Agriculture and Engineering, Guangzhou, China; School of Intelligent Manufacturing, Wuyi University, Jiangmen, China
Publication Title: IEEE Access
Abstract: Accurately diagnosing crop diseases is crucial for agricultural productivity and food safety. This study addresses the challenge by developing an AI crop disease diagnosis platform, leveraging the strengths of Convolution Neural Networks (CNNs) and Vision Transformers. The proposed Convolution Self-Guided Transformer (CSGT) model integrates CNN’s local feature extraction with the Self-Guided Transformer’s(SGT) global information processing, enhancing the precision and efficiency of agricultural diagnostics. We selected two datasets with characteristics from Jiangsu and Guangdong provinces to validate our model, respectively representing controlled and uncontrolled agricultural environments. The CSGT model demonstrates exceptional performance in diagnosing crop diseases across diverse backgrounds, overcoming the limitations of current models, especially in complex settings. The CSGT model’s CNN layer, hybrid-scale, and self-guided attention mechanisms ensure accurate diagnoses, even in the presence of background clutter. CSGT has an accuracy of 96.9%(Apple),95.8%(Corn), 96.1%(Grape), and 96.5%(Tomato) when classifying crop diseases in a stable environment, and 95.8%(Rice) when classifying diseases in a complex environment. The research results are anticipated to enhance the effectiveness and stability of natural crop disease recognition applications.

Abstract: Crop Monitoring System (CMS) presented in this paper leverages GSM technology to establish a robust framework for real-time crop field management and optimization [1]. The system is comprised of an array of intelligent sensors, a high-performance microcontroller, a GSM communication module, a centralized server infrastructure, and an intuitive web interface [2]. This integrated solution offers farmers and agriculturists unprecedented insights into crop conditions, enabling informed decision-making for en-hanced yield and resource conservation. The operational workflow of CMS encompasses several distinct phases. Beginning with precise data collection, a suite of specialized sensors captures vital parameters such as ambient temperature, humidity, soil moisture, and light intensity. This data forms the foundation for informedcrop analysis. The microcontroller undertakes the task of processing raw sensor data, converting it into a digital format suitable for transmission [5]. The GSM module facilitates seamless data transfer over the cellular network to a remote server, ensuring data integrity and security. The heart of CMS lies within its centralized server infrastructure, where a robust database stores the transmitted data. A user-friendly web interface translates this data into visually comprehensible graphs, charts, and real-time updates, enabling users to monitor crop conditions remotely [10]. Furthermore, the system employs pre-defined thresholds to generate timely alerts when any parameter deviates from the acceptable range [9]. This feature empowers farmers to take proactive measures to safeguard crop health and optimize yields. An innovative facet of CMS is its remote control capability, enabling users to manage irrigation systems and other equipment remotely. This dynamic feature streamlines agricultural operations, allowing for precision adjustments in response to real-time data, thus minimizing resource wastage and fostering sustainable practices

This paper deals with examining disease recognition and classification in paddy leaves using the new methodologies of machine learning. The study works on a large-scale paddy leaf image dataset. We deployed MobileNetV2, an image-processing CNN model, on a large-scale paddy leaf image dataset to detect and classify common diseases such as bacterial blight, brown spots, and leaf blasts. The model achieved a validation accuracy of 96.97 % and a significant improvement in performance after fine-tuning, highlighting the impact of feature extraction techniques, data augmentation, and hyperparameter tuning on performance stability.

Abstract: Using a network of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), the research presents a novel method for paddy crop disease detection. To increase agricultural productivity and quality in the face of a growing global demand for food, accurate disease identification is essential. This proposes a method that uses a weighted voting mechanism to combine the predictive potential of multiple CNN architectures to improve disease categorization precision and robustness. Extensive testing on a large dataset demonstrates that the ensemble CNNs outperform both the individual CNNs and the current best practices. Not only does the ensemble technique increase the accuracy of disease diagnosis, but it also demonstrates remarkable stability in the face of variations in image quality and disease symptoms. Our research contributes to the development of precision agricultural operations and the promotion of sustainable crop management through the efficient application of CNN ensembles. In order to ensure the safety of the world's food supply, it is necessary to improve current methods of disease detection and prevention, according to the findings of this study employing deep learning techniques.

Abstract: Mosaic Virus is highly responsible for the crop loss, especially the pepper, which is considered part of food crop, an essential aspect of world’s agriculture. This work aims at automating the classification of disease severity level-related the Pepper Leaf Mosaic Virus Disease threshold through vision transformer (ViT) model to ensure a critical job. The classification of the severity is more often accompanied by a fairly significant amount of workload and arbitrariness, resulting in equipment innovation in most of the locations. The work applies ViT-based approaches with sufficient precision to appropriately classify a dataset, which contains 10,800 meticulously selected photographs. The present model obtained a commendable average accuracy of 97.25%, which shows that the model was able to detect even smaller differences between the classes of severity. The operational criteria that include the tale of the precision, recall, and F1-score highlight the model’s ability to minimize to Feggsor false Positives with its ability to discriminate cases of viruses at different levels of the spectrum. The more advanced comparison charts made hand methodologies stand at the pinnacle in plant pathology studies. This study is not only beneficial in terms of illuminating the understanding about the Pepper Leaf Mosaic Virus but also gives farmers and researchers a transformative tool that could change the way disease control methods are used. Technologies AI that power ViT model are helping the agriculture industries throughout the world to implement sustainability and resiliency of the systems by providing responses in the right time and place in addressing viral infections.

Abstract: Soil organic carbon (SOC) content is a key indicator of soil health informing about sustainable land management practices, but parcel-wide SOC mapping is challenging as it requires high-resolution data. Unoccupied Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) can collect data with cm-resolution but are not yet fully ready to be practically implemented. The aim of this study is to provide more insights in the explanatory capabilities of UAV-derived spectral and topographical variables. To this end, mixed models were employed to estimate the SOC content of three agricultural parcels with different crop types in Greece. Results showed variations in SOC content among parcels, with a vineyard and a kiwi orchard having higher values compared to a peach orchard. All models, containing topographical and/or spectral variables, explained 81% of SOC content variation of the training dataset. Besides crop type, other topographical and spectral variables were identified as significant predictors. The study emphasizes the feasibility of UAV data and specific modeling techniques for accurate SOC estimation at the parcel level, providing valuable insights for precision agriculture. The findings recommend further exploration, including machine-learning approaches in future studies.

Abstract: Agriculture has long faced challenges from harmful insect pests, including those affecting sugarcane, a vital crop in Indonesia. Traditional control methods such as insecticides and pest monitoring techniques have been employed to mitigate the impact of these pests. In the context of precision agriculture, artificial intelligence (AI) technology enables the efficient detection and classification of organisms. One AI technique, deep learning, has been widely applied in the classification of plant diseases. This research focuses on the application of deep learning for the classification of sugarcane diseases. We propose a deep learning network architecture that integrates EfficientNetV2B0 with Dual Convolution Spatial Attention CBAM (DCSA-CBAM) to enhance the features of infected sugarcane leaf images. This paper introduces a new dataset comprising 1968 sugarcane leaf images from various regions in East Java. Our proposed model achieved an accuracy of $\mathbf{9 4 . 2 \%}$, demonstrating strong performance in classifying sugarcane diseases. We also compare the performance of several other deep learning networks, including DenseNet, MobileNet, ResNet, and VGG with our model showing superior results.

Document Title: EfficientNetB0-Based Deep Learning Approach for Crop Growth Stage Classification
Authors: B. S. Priya; R. L. Sai Ram; M. Manojkumar; T. R. Vennam; V. Murthy; G. B. Regulwar
Author Affiliations: Department of Information Technology, Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, Telangana, India; Department of Information Technology, Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, Telangana, India; Department of Information Technology, Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, Telangana, India; Department of Information Technology, Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, Telangana, India; Department of Information Technology, Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, Telangana, India; Department of Information Technology, Vardhaman College of Engineering, Hyderabad, Telangana, India
Publication Title: 2024 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence Trends and Pattern Recognition (ICAITPR)
Abstract: This paper thoroughly examines the employment of the highly potent EfficientNetB0 convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture for image-based growth phase classification of maize crops, aiming to advance precision agriculture by automating key management and monitoring activities. This project seeks to increase agricultural productivity and efficiency through the application of modern deep-learning algorithms. The methodology begins with the preprocessing of a comprehensive dataset of maize crop images. These images are resized to 224x224 pixels to ensure uniformity and standardization across the dataset, which is crucial for the effective training of the CNN. Pixel values are also standardized to optimize the model's preparation phase. Transfer learning is employed, utilizing pre-trained ImageNet weights, which facilitates faster convergence and improves predictive accuracy by leveraging the vast amount of knowledge already embedded in the EfficientNetB0 model. EfficientNetB0 serves as the foundational architecture due to its balanced trade-off between efficiency and accuracy. The model's design includes dropout regularization techniques to mitigate overfitting, which is essential for maintaining generalizability to unseen data. Dense layers are incorporated for hierarchical feature extraction, while global average pooling is used for feature aggregation, reducing the risk of overfitting and maintaining model efficiency. Batch normalization is used to provide consistent learning rates across all layers of the model and to expedite and stabilize the training process. TensorFlow and Keras, powerful deep learning frameworks, are utilized to build and train the model. The classification results demonstrate the model's capability to accurately distinguish between different growth stages of maize crops based solely on images. This accuracy is validated through various benchmarks that assess the model's performance during both the training and validation phases, focusing on metrics such as loss and accuracy. The model's proficiency in accurately predicting maize crop growth stages is further evidenced by its performance on an unseen test set, showcasing its potential for scaling in agricultural monitoring systems. By integrating advanced deep learning techniques, this research contributes significantly to the field of agricultural technology, optimizing production management practices and enhancing yield prediction accuracy. While the primary focus has been on maize, the model shows promise for application to a broader range of crops. Future improvements may include refining the dataset and developing more sophisticated neural networks to achieve even higher accuracy across diverse crops and agricultural environments.
Author Keywords: EfficientNetB0;convolutional neural network;crop growth stages;precision agriculture;maize crop;image classification
IEEE Terms: Deep learning;Training;Precision agriculture;Accuracy;Crops;Predictive models;Convolutional neural networks;Monitoring;Overfitting;Meteorology

Author Affiliations: Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, India
Publication Title: 2023 Fourth International Conference on Smart Technologies in Computing, Electrical and Electronics (ICSTCEE)
Abstract: This study explores the novel use of federated learning in conjunction with CNN for illness classification in Aloe vera leaves. Five separate client-contributed classes of Aloe Vera leaf diseases form the basis of the dataset used in the research. The technique is centered on using federated learning to create a decentralized data analysis system that protects privacy. Each client's local datasets are used to create a model that is optimized worldwide. The examination of the results included a thorough evaluation of the model's performance across all five customers (nh_1 to nh_5) using a variety of statistical metrics. To provide a complete picture of the model's performance, compute the macro, micro, and weighted averages. Results showed that nh_1, nh_2, nh_3, nh_4, and nh_5 all had macro standards of 88.61%, 84.07%, 80.08%, 90.02%, and 94.16%, respectively, indicating that the model performed evenly across all classes. Using weighted averages, which take into account the class imbalance, further analysis revealed that nh_5 was in the lead at 94.25%, followed by nh_4 at 90.04%, nh_1 at 88.97%, nh_2 at 84.45%, and nh_3 at 80.13%. Micro averages, which take into account all classes' contributions, con firmed similar findings: NH 5 achieved 94.25%, NH 4 gained 90.04%, NH 1 reached 88.94%, NH 2 achieved 84.49%, and NH 3 achieved 80.15%. In particular, for agricultural disease identification, the study's major contribution is the way it shows how federated learning may be used to merge local data into a strong global model.

Abstract: Agricultural productivity faces significant threats from plant diseases, leading to substantial economic losses and worsening global food insecurity. These diseases can drastically reduce crop yields, adversely affecting farmers' livelihoods and disrupting food supply chains. In response, agrotechnology and precision farming have emerged as critical solutions, emphasizing the need for sustainable crop management through accurate and timely disease detection. Early intervention is essential to minimize disease spread and enhance understanding of crop health. This study presents a comprehensive approach to plant disease classification using a combination of autoencoders for dimensionality reduction and a fine-tuned ResNet-9 architecture. The proposed methodology leverages the autoencoder to effectively reduce the dimensionality of leaf imagery data, thereby simplifying the feature space and improving computational efficiency. The reduced features are then fed into a ResNet-9 model, which has been fine-tuned to achieve high classification accuracy for various plant diseases. Our model achieves a remarkable accuracy of 99.2%. The development of this robust tool aims to facilitate early disease detection and improve crop management, contributing significantly to the field of precision agriculture. By providing precise and timely diagnoses ofplant health, deep learning models hold the potential to revolutionize agricultural practices, thereby enhancing yield and sustainability in food production.

Abstract: Rice is a basic food for more than half of the world's population, which highlights the crop's significance in global agriculture. But growing rice is a difficult undertaking, with the most significant obstacle being the constant barrage of biotic stresses-most notably diseases-that jeopardize crop output and health. This research paper examines how well-trained Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architectures can improve rice leaf disease prediction. In this paper, multiple pre-trained CNN models (VGG16, Inception, MobileNetV2, DenseNet, and Xception) are assessed using transfer learning on a dataset of images of rice leaves with different illnesses. Main goal of this paper is to determine which model works best for correctly categorizing rice leaf diseases from their visual symptoms. Authors have determined, via thorough testing and analysis that Xception performs better than other architectures in terms of correctly forecasting rice leaf illnesses with 86.90% and 75.00% accuracy on training and testing data, respectively. This research provides important insights into the use of pre-trained CNN architectures for better rice disease diagnosis.

Document Title: Environmental friendly and low cost monitoring system for plant and agriculture fields
Authors: S. Voigt; A. Willert; W. Mende; T. Zschau; T. Oehme; R. Zichner
Author Affiliations: Fraunhofer ENAS, Chemnitz, Germany; Fraunhofer ENAS, Chemnitz, Germany; Fraunhofer ENAS, Chemnitz, Germany; Fraunhofer ENAS, Chemnitz, Germany; Fraunhofer ENAS, Chemnitz, Germany; Fraunhofer ENAS, Chemnitz, Germany
Publication Title: 2023 Smart Systems Integration Conference and Exhibition (SSI)
Abstract: The constantly growing global population is to be sustainably supplied with food. Due to climatic changes and increasing problems in protecting the environment, farmers are faced with great challenges. In order to automate, specify and simplify processes, reliable decision-making bases for the control of irrigation, fertilization and plant protection measures with a close-meshed database are required. This can be achieved with cost-efficiently produced and environmentally friendly sensor systems for monitoring cultivated areas. Such a monitoring system is currently being developed, first laboratory samples are available and are being tested step by step in laboratory and field. The single sensor devices consist of a miniaturized electronic module with single-chip radio system, sensors for measuring temperature, soil tension, in the near future leaf wetness and nitrate. The sensors and the electronic module are fabricated from materials that are biodegradable or inert with a minimum amount of metal and ceramic and allow for remaining them on the field when harvesting. The device is powered by a biodegradable zinc-manganese dioxide battery. For wireless communication, a printed antenna on a wood carrier is used. A gateway collects the data transmitted by the distributed sensor devices and brings it to the internet to a central server running an expert system. The technologies used for the assembly, such as roll-to-roll and screen printing, and the materials used, such as wood and paper, enable inexpensive and partly biodegradable sensors that are applied to the field once per growing season in high density. This enables fine-mesh, site-specific treatments and a further reduction in water, fertiliser and pesticide use.
Funding Information: Federal Ministry of Education and Research(grant numbers:16MEO160);

Document Title: Evaluate the Winter Wheat GVMI and NDMI correlations with the Rainfall
Authors: Y. Li; S. Dhelim; L. Chen; M. T. Kechadi
Author Affiliations: School of Computer Science, University College Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; School of Computer, Dublin City University, Dublin, Ireland; School of Computer Science and Technology, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, Liaoning, China; School of Computer Science, University College Dublin, Dublin, Ireland
Publication Title: 2024 IEEE Smart World Congress (SWC)
Abstract: With the recent application of digital twin systems in smart agriculture, the intricate relationships between different data types have become increasingly significant, particularly the correlation between satellite data and weather data. This correlation is a critical aspect of advanced agricultural monitoring. This study examined the relationship between two satellitederived indices, GVMI and NDMI, which reflect leaf moisture content, and rainfall. Our analysis reveals a strong correlation between GVMI and NDMI, with a coefficient as high as 0.97, while their correlation with rainfall is minimal. Consequently, future research will further explore the impact of rainfall on these indices. Specifically, we investigated whether substantial increases in these indices are linked to rainfall and examined the correlation between their growth rates and rainfall. Our findings indicate that approximately 70% of significant increases are attributed to rainfall. Additionally, due to the inherent lag in satellite data’s response to rainfall-—here substantial changes may not be immediate but require some time to manifest—we explored the time lag needed for significant changes in NDMI and GVMI to occur after rainfall. The results demonstrate that NDMI is more sensitive and reacts more quickly to rainfall, with $\mathbf{9 2 \%}$ of the data showing significant increases or decreases within two days following rainfall, compared to $\mathbf{7 0 \%}$ for GVMI.
Author Keywords: Digital twins;Sentinel Images;Meteorology Dataset;GVMI;NDMI
IEEE Terms: Smart agriculture;Rain;Correlation;Satellites;Fluctuations;Stability criteria;Moisture;Crops;Digital twins;Meteorology

Abstract: As the global population continues to grow, the demand for food intensifies, making precision agriculture essential for enhancing productivity and resource efficiency. A critical component of precision agriculture is accurate crop mapping, which enables optimized resource allocation and better yield prediction. This study focuses on developing a machine learning-based predictive model for crop mapping using multispectral remote sensing data from the Senegalese groundnut basin. The dataset, collected via Sentinel-2 satellites, includes optical bands and vegetation indices over four time periods in 2023. After preprocessing and addressing class imbalance through data augmentation and SMOTE, several machine learning models were evaluated, with Random Forest emerging as the most effective. The results show a significant improvement in classification accuracy, particularly for underrepresented crop types, with the Random Forest model achieving 93.57% accuracy after SMOTE, compared to 57.43% before SMOTE. The outcomes of this research extend beyond technological advancements, contributing to environmental sustainability by enabling more precise resource use, reducing waste, and minimizing the environmental impact of agricultural practices. Furthermore, this type of crop mapping supports food security by helping farmers optimize yields and manage crops more effectively, directly benefiting communities reliant on agriculture. The integration of machine learning and remote sensing in precision agriculture has the potential to foster a more resilient and sustainable agricultural system globally.

To increase the crop yield, the proposed technique of implementing real-time prediction of crop yield IOT monitoring system called Digital Intelligence Farming Techniques (DIFT) uses a Fuzzy Inference System (FIS) to make decisions effectively and efficiently through the mobile application. Document Title: Fault Localization of Statement Coverage Based on DNN
Authors: L. Peng; C. Mi
Author Affiliations: School of Computer Science and Engineering, Huaihua University; School of Computer Science and Engineering, Huaihua University
Publication Title: 2021 International Conference on Electronic Information Technology and Smart Agriculture (ICEITSA)
Abstract: In view of the inconvenience of parameter setting in the existing fault location method based on deep neural network, this paper combines the global random search ability of Genetic Algorithm, L2 regularization to prevent model overfitting and deep neural network to learn complex nonlinear ability, a fault location algorithm based on G-DNN is proposed. The optimal number of hidden layer neurons, learning rate, training period and L2 regularization coefficient of deep neural network are obtained by Genetic Algorithm; Input the statement coverage information and state values into the deep neural network to calculate the suspiciousness value of each executable statement; Locate defects from high to low according to the suspiciousness values. The Siemens Suite is used as the experimental sample, and the G-DNN is compared with the five defect location algorithms. The results show that the defect of the G-DNN can locate defects more accurately, and the positioning efficiency is improved.
Author Keywords: component;Genetic Algorithm;L2 regularization;Deep Neural Network;Fault Location;Statement Coverage
IEEE Terms: Deep learning;Training;Location awareness;Neurons;Fault location;Information technology;Biological neural networks

Document Title: Fine-Tuning-Powered Plant Disease Detection Based on Cloud-Edge Computing in Smart Farms
Authors: D. Meng; W. Jiang; W. Jin
Author Affiliations: Department of Electronic & Communication Engineering, Yanbian University, Yanji, China; Department of Electronic & Communication Engineering, Yanbian University, Yanji, China; Department of Electronic & Communication Engineering, Yanbian University, Yanji, China
Publication Title: 2024 4th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
Abstract: Plants are an indispensable part of agricultural production, and the study of plant disease classification and recognition has an important impact on garden horticulture, environmental protection, crop growth and the continuous development of agricultural economy. Moreover, it plays a very important role in crop production intelligence and crop big data management applications. Traditional machine learning relies too much on expert knowledge, and the form of artificial extraction of plant leaf information cannot meet the recognition of complex diseases. In this paper, we come up with an edge-cloud plant disease classification approach by using fine-tuning to improve the performance continuously. Methods of crop disease identification leverages convolutional neural networks (CNN) that achieves successful performance in various computer vision tasks. The improved leaf recognition model performs the collection, analysis, processing and prediction of heterogeneous data in the process of crop planting. The proposed fine-tunning-improved CNN model is used for searching three common potato diseases in real time. In the cloud, the dataset is deployed to derive the prediction model using CNN for performing fine-tuning in the edge device. Based on the presented approach, the performance of the model is improved and the time consuming decreased by fine-tuning method in the edge environment.
Author Keywords: deep learning;convolutional neural networks;fine-tuning training;disease detection;smart farm
IEEE Terms: Performance evaluation;Plant diseases;Computational modeling;Image edge detection;Crops;Production;Predictive models;Data models;Convolutional neural networks;Tuning

Document Title: From Pixels to Insights: Transforming Plant Pathology with Artificial Intelligence
Authors: R. Bhuria; K. S. Gill; N. Thapliyal; R. S. Rawat
Author Affiliations: Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Computer Science & Engineering, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, India; Computer Science & Engineering, Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, India
Publication Title: 2024 IEEE 3rd World Conference on Applied Intelligence and Computing (AIC)
Abstract: We urgently want more precise methods of detecting plant diseases because they pose an increasing danger to the global food supply. Finding a solution to this challenge utilising state-of-the-art deep learning technology is the focus of this research. Various models' abilities to diagnose plant diseases are examined in the study. Squeezenet1_1, VGG13, Inception_v3, ResNet34, DenseNet169, and AlexNet are among the models it examines. Included in the data set is a background class from the DAGS dataset in addition to 38 distinct plant diseases culled from the PlantVillage dataset on Kaggle. The results demonstrate that various designs and training methods exhibit slight variations in performance. For instance, after extensive retraining, AlexNet achieves an accuracy of 99.24%. However, after extensive retraining, DenseNet169 achieves an impressive 99.72% accuracy. In order to have a deeper grasp of the models' behaviour, the research incorporates visualisation experiments with accuracy measurements. In the occlusion experiment, we can see heat maps that graphically depict how various picture elements impact the program's decision-making. In order to determine which pixels are most relevant, the saliency map experiment use mathematics. This sheds light on the decision-making process of the model. Utilising AlexNet and VGG13, pictures of specific plant diseases such as Septoria Leaf Spot, Early Blight, and Late Blight are displayed. To summarise, this article discusses the inner workings of various deep learning models for plant disease detection and compares them. The findings aid in selecting optimal models and training strategies, which in turn facilitates the development of robust and reliable automated systems for disease diagnosis in plants. Using cutting-edge technologies, this study represents a major step towards improving agricultural disease detection.
Author Keywords: Deep Learning;Plant Disease Detection;Convolutional Neural Networks;Occlusion Experiment;Saliency Map;PyTorch;Model Visualization;Interpretability;Agriculture
IEEE Terms: Deep learning;Training;Plant diseases;Visualization;Pathology;Analytical models;Accuracy;Decision making;Mathematical models;Reliability

Document Title: Global Sensitivity Analysis of Polarimetric Data to Retrieve Biophysical Parameters of Canola and Barley Crops
Authors: E. Erten; G. Taskin; J. M. Lopez-Sanchez
Author Affiliations: Faculty of Science, The Open University, Milton Keynes, United Kingdom; Institute of Earthquake Engineering and Disaster Management, Istanbul Technical University, Istanbul, Turkey; Institute of Computing Research, University of Alicante, Alicante, Spain
Publication Title: IGARSS 2018 - 2018 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
Abstract: Tracking crop's biophysical parameters using temporal Pol-SAR (Polarimetric Synthetic Aperture Radar Data) data is an active research topic in precision agriculture due to the sensitivity of PolSAR acquisition to canopy's physical and geometrical structure. Reconstruction of polarimetric features from collection of SAR data is computationally expensive, and more important, the inter-features correlations cause decreased performance in regression based biophysical parameter estimation. With the scope of operational crop monitoring, this study provides key variables to drive Leaf Area Index (LAI) from polarimetric data based on global sensitivity analysis (GSA) addressing the ranking of the most influential features. We applied variance-based GSA for temporal fully-polarimetric RadarSAt-2 images acquired through the cultivation period of two crops; canola and barley. Among 20 polarimetric features, anisotropy and correlation magnitude between co-polar channels were found to be the most influential polarimetric features for canola and barley, respectively.
Author Keywords: Polarimetry;SAR;precision agriculture;monitoring;LAI;optimization;metamodels
IEEE Terms: Agriculture;Sensitivity analysis;Ground penetrating radar;Training;Synthetic aperture radar;Correlation

Document Title: Global research trends in agro-geoinformatics during 1991–2015: A bibliometric analysis
Authors: X. Chen; B. Wang; J. Zhang
Author Affiliations: School of Resources and Environmental Sci., Wuhan University, Wuhan, Hubei, China; School of Resources and Environmental Sci., Wuhan University, Wuhan, Hubei, China; School of Resources and Environmental Sci., Wuhan University, Wuhan, Hubei, China
Publication Title: 2017 6th International Conference on Agro-Geoinformatics
Abstract: A bibliometric analysis was conducted to evaluate agro-geoinformatics research from different perspectives during 1991-2015 based on the SCIE and SSCI databases. According to 15,127 document samples related to agro-geoinformatics, the bibliometric analysis was firstly identified by general patterns for publication outputs, subject categories and major journals related to agro-geoinformatics research. Then it evaluated productivity and performance in the level of author institution and country, and revealed the characteristics of authors' geographic distributions and international collaborations. What's more, it analyzed temporal trends in keywords usage in agro-geoinformatics studies. Additionally, it summarized global research trends from multiple perspectives to provide an alternative demonstration of research advancements, which may serve as a potential guide for futuristic research related to agro-geoinformatics. agro-geoinformatics-related research has undergone notable growth during the past 25 years. remote sensing, environmental sciences, and imaging science photographic technology were the 3 major science categories. International Journal of Remote Sensing was the most active journal in terms of quantity during the surveyed period and Remote Sensing of Environment has the biggest contribution in quantity. Pradhan, B from Univ Putra Malaysia was the most active author as corresponding author. Kustas, WP from USDA ARS was the most productive author as first author. And Weng, QH from Indiana State Univ had the most highly-qualified documents. The major author clusters and research regions are located in North America, Western Europe, and East Asia. The Chinese Academy of Sciences, USDA ARS and NASA were the 3 major contributing institutions. However, USA was a leading contributor to global agro-geoinformatics research. With the most independent and collaborative articles, its dominance is also confirmed in the national/regional collaboration network. And a keyword analysis has found that effective research technologies and methods were promising topics attracting the most attention during the study period. Several keywords, such as “remote sensing”, “GIS”, “Precision agriculture”, “soil moisture” and “NDVI” have received dramatically increasing attention during the study period, which is possibly signaling the future research trends.
Author Keywords: bibliometric;agro-geoinformatics;Research trend;Scientific outputs
IEEE Terms: Productivity;Bibliometrics;NASA;Collaboration;Imaging;Market research;International collaboration

Document Title: Hybrid Vision Transformer and CNN for Detection of Overripe Coffee Berry Disease (OCBD) in Coffee Plantation
Authors: R. Selvanarayanan; S. R; G. T; K. L
Author Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Saveetha School of Engineering Saveetha Institute of Medical and Technical Science, Chennai, India; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Saveetha School of Engineering Saveetha Institute of Medical and Technical Science, Chennai, India; Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Sathyabama Institute of Science and Technology, Chennai, India; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Vel Tech Rangarajan Dr.Sangunthala R&D Institute of Science and Technology, Chennai, India
Publication Title: 2024 International Conference on Emerging Research in Computational Science (ICERCS)
Abstract: The article proposes an innovative Hybrid Vision Transformer and CNN architecture for the precise identification of Overripe Coffee Berry Disease (OCBD) in coffee farms. The suggested model adeptly integrates the advantages of Vision Transformers and CNNs, allowing it to capture both the global and local characteristics of coffee berries. Experimental findings indicate that the Hybrid model outperforms conventional CNN-based methods, with an impressive accuracy of 96.7% on a varied dataset. The model's resilience to fluctuating illumination conditions and obstructions makes it a viable alternative for practical applications in coffee plantation management.

Document Title: Identification and Classification of Crop Diseases Using Transfer Learning Based Convolution Neural Network
Authors: S. Mehta; Vanshika; A. P. Singh; S. Singh; G. Singh
Author Affiliations: Department of AIT-CSE, Chandigarh University, Punjab, India; Department of AIT-CSE, Chandigarh University, Punjab, India; Department of AIT-CSE, Chandigarh University, Punjab, India; Department of AIT-CSE, Chandigarh University, Punjab, India; Department of AIT-CSE, Chandigarh University, Punjab, India
Publication Title: 2023 International Conference on Advanced & Global Engineering Challenges (AGEC)
Abstract: Pests and diseases can have a major impact on the apple industry. Apple crops are susceptible to a range of diseases that can do a lot of harm to the fruit and the trees, reducing yields and affecting the quality of the apples. This, in turn, leads to lower revenues for growers and a higher cost of production. The symptoms of different apple diseases can sometimes be similar, making it difficult for farmers to accurately diagnose the problem and choose the appropriate treatment. In some cases, multiple diseases can occur simultaneously, further complicating the diagnosis and management of the problem. To overcome this challenge, an initiative is conceptualized to provide a quick and precise apple disease detection and classification. In this paper, a deep learning based approach for classifying and identifying apple diseases has been proposed wherein the generated dataset is fed into a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model which comprises the object identification (for locating & identifying objects of interest in an image), segmentation (for separating the objects from the background), and image classification (for assigning each object to a specific class or category). Further data augmentation methods including scaling, rotation, reflection were also incorporated for better learning of underlying patterns in the data, leading to improved generalization and reduced over-fitting. The proposed CNN method achieved impressive results, scoring about 97.06 % accuracy as well as better score for other evaluating metrics, such as precision, recall, or F1-score. Therefore, by using a CNN model to accurately diagnose different apple diseases, farmers can make informed decisions about how to manage their crops, leading to improved yields and higher revenues.
Author Keywords: Crop yield;Deep learning;Prediction accuracy;Data augmentation
IEEE Terms: Measurement;Industries;Transfer learning;Neural networks;Crops;Production;Reflection

Document Title: Impact of Federated Learning in Agriculture 4.0: Collaborative Analysis of Distributed Agricultural Data
Authors: A. K. Gaur; J. Arul Valan
Author Affiliations: National Institute of Technology Nagaland, Dimapur; National Institute of Technology Nagaland, Dimapur
Publication Title: 2024 2nd World Conference on Communication & Computing (WCONF)
Abstract: Agriculture 4.0 integrates traditional farming methods with advanced technologies, yet its adoption faces significant challenges. This article identifies these obstacles and proposes leveraging Federated Learning (FL) to overcome them. However, the application of federating machine learning algorithms within the agricultural domain is still in its infancy. We introduce the Federated Learning Assisted Agriculture 4.0 (AgriFL 4.0) framework, designed to ensure privacy while collaboratively analyzing distributed agricultural data. Within AgriFL 4.0, a common Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) model is trained locally to analyze decentralized agricultural data. Additionally, a consolidated model is formed at the server using the Federated Average aggregation technique. For this study, we employ the Dry Bean Dataset from Kaggle, assembled in 2020, consisting of 13,611 instances with 16 attributes, including dimensions and shape forms crucial for seed classification. To evaluate AgriFL 4.0's performance on horizontally distributed agricultural data, we categorize the dataset into two types: lID and non-lID. In our simulation involving 10 clients, we explored scenarios featuring 0%, 40%, and 80% stragglers-nodes encountering delays. Moreover, we compare the federated and non-federated model performances. The results indicate that the framework works well with lID data, and the federated model outperforms the non-federated model in terms of classification accuracy and other performance metrics. However, with non-lID data, the framework's performance degrades as the count of stragglers increases. This underscores the critical role of federated learning in advancing Agriculture 4.0.
Author Keywords: Federated Learning;Agriculture 4.0;Distributed Optimization;Multiclass Classification
IEEE Terms: Training;Data privacy;Technological innovation;Accuracy;Federated learning;Distributed databases;Collaboration;Agriculture;Data models;Sustainable development

Document Title: Implementation of Data Collecting Platform Over Distributed Sensors for Global Open Data for Agriculture and Nutrition
Authors: Yuyanto; S. Liawatimena
Author Affiliations: Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Publication Title: 2018 6th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management (CITSM)
Abstract: Agriculture nowadays deals with numerous factors to support the success of the harvest, such as temperature, air pressure, air humidity, sunlight, soil moisture, rainfall. With so much data that can be collected and analyzed, it is expected to create an early warning system if there are parameters that are already in the critical value and are at risk of causing crop failure. As information technology is developing rapidly, it could be utilized as a tool to support the effort in facing this issue. this study will focus on providing a reliable open data platform which is accessible to relevant stakeholders Google Cloud Platform is selected to serve this purpose to mitigate the risk of maintaining a reliable high availability platform. Google Cloud IoT Core is configured to accept MQTT protocol message sent by sensors. Other google cloud functionality will be configured to store the message into google NoSQL database. Google cloud function will be used to provide data if any request of data to server is being made through REST webservice call. As a result, all the configured Google functionalities are able to synchronize to store and retrieve data.
Author Keywords: Big Data Application;Data Integration;Internet of Things;Mobile Applications;Web Services
IEEE Terms: Cloud computing;Google;Sensors;Agriculture;Reliability;Telemetry;Security

Document Title: Innovative Solutions for Crop Health A Hybrid Approach to Cotton Root Rot Severity Assessment
Authors: G. Rana; D. Banerjee; R. Chauhan; M. Singh; B. V. Kumar
Author Affiliations: VLSI Centre of Excellence, Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, India; Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, India; School of Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence, SR University, Warangal, India
Publication Title: 2024 4th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
Abstract: The proposed study aims to enhance our comprehension and control of the gravity of cotton root rot by integrating agricultural practices with technological advancements. The combination of a CNN, which possesses knowledge, with an SVM greatly enhances its ability to detect root rot. It possesses great strength, exhibits high adaptability, and demonstrates exceptional speed in task execution. The test results indicate that Cotton, a significant component of global agriculture, is currently confronted with a persistent issue caused by detrimental root rot. The cause of this issue is Phymatotrichopsis omnivora, which has the potential to negatively impact productivity if not well managed. Effectively managing illnesses relies on meticulous and prompt attention to the severity of root rot. Executing this challenging undertaking requires innovative concepts to achieve success. This study used a mixed model as a response. The method combines the properties of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Support Vector Machine (SVM) to develop a sophisticated approach for quantifying the severity of cotton root rot infections. Our inquiry starts with a substantial collection of 9,000 dispersed photographs. These high-resolution photographs depict the several manifestations of root rot in plants in proximity. Demonstrating the effectiveness of our blend model, we present a comprehensive accuracy rate of 98.56%. This demonstrates its proficiency in providing accurate and comprehensive threat assessments. The model’s accuracy, memory recall, and F1 score serve as indicators of its performance.
Author Keywords: cotton;hybrid model;dataset curation;disease management;deep learning;root rot;precision agriculture
IEEE Terms: Support vector machines;Adaptation models;Accuracy;Music;Data models;Threat assessment;Numerical models;Cotton;Convolutional neural networks;Gravity

Document Title: Integration of CNN and Transformer for Regularized Extraction of Agricultural Parcels from High-Resolution Remote Sensing Images
Authors: C. Lu; M. Li; X. Xiu; J. Long; C. Zhang
Author Affiliations: Key Lab of Spatial Data Mining & Information Sharing of Ministry of Education Academy of Digital China (Fujian), Fuzhou University, FuZhou, China; Key Lab of Spatial Data Mining & Information Sharing of Ministry of Education Academy of Digital China (Fujian), Fuzhou University, FuZhou, China; Geological Remote Sensing Center, Fujian Geological Survey and Mapping Institute, FuZhou, China; Key Lab of Spatial Data Mining & Information Sharing of Ministry of Education Academy of Digital China (Fujian), Fuzhou University, FuZhou, China; Key Lab of Spatial Data Mining & Information Sharing of Ministry of Education Academy of Digital China (Fujian), Fuzhou University, FuZhou, China
Publication Title: 2024 8th Asian Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ACAIT)
Abstract: Agricultural parcels are the fundamental spatial units of precision agricultural practices. However, in southern regions, the parcels tend to be small, structurally complex, and fragmented, posing challenges for precise extraction using existing convolutional neural network (CNNs) based on deep learning. To address these issues, we introduced a novel neural network model, i.e., CLCFormer, which combines CNN and Swin-Transformer. This model leverages the strengths of CNN in capturing fine-grained spatial details and the ability of Transformer in extracting global semantic features. We introduced three distinct modules to refine the learning of spatial features, enhance the accuracy of parcel extraction in mountainous and hilly regions, and mitigate the boundary blurriness caused by occluded objects. Finally, we employed a post-processing method to achieve regularized parcel extraction. Our study was tested on GF-2 high-resolution remote sensing datasets from Nanping and Fuzhou, Fujian Province, China. Our proposed method achieved a prediction precision of 86.68% and a recall rate of 85.3% on the Nanping test set, and maintaining a transfer precision of 85.67% on the Fuzhou dataset. Compared to other advanced parcel extraction models, our method demonstrates the highest performance. Moreover, the extracted parcels have the highest consistency with the actual distribution patterns of agricultural parcels. We provided a practical approach for precise extraction of agricultural parcels information at the parcel scale.
Author Keywords: agricultural parcels extraction;high-resolution images;clcformer;swin-transformer
IEEE Terms: Deep learning;Semantics;Neural networks;Vegetation mapping;Feature extraction;Transformers;Vectors;Robustness;Convolutional neural networks;Remote sensing

Document Title: Leaf Analysis for Disease Identification using Transfer learning
Authors: R. Beniwal; S. Sachin; S. Satyam; S. Kumar
Author Affiliations: Department of Computer Science & Engineering, Delhi Technological University, Delhi, India; Department of Computer Science & Engineering, Delhi Technological University, Delhi, India; Department of Computer Science & Engineering, Delhi Technological University, Delhi, India; Department of Computer Science & Engineering, Delhi Technological University, Delhi, India
Publication Title: 2024 International Conference on Circuit, Systems and Communication (ICCSC)
Abstract: The escalating challenges in agricultural efficiency due to plant diseases require advanced solutions for early detection and administration. Conventional strategies, despite being viable to a degree, need the exactness, speed, and adaptability required to relieve these challenges effectively. This research presents a novel approach to plant disease identification leveraging the control of transfer learning. By focusing on basic crops such as wheat, rice, corn, and sugarcane, this study points to revolutionizing leaf investigation for disease location, advertising a critical jump toward precision agriculture. Utilizing a comprehensive dataset comprising pictures of solid and unhealthy clears out, we prepared and assessed models for each trim, accomplishing exceptional exactnesses: 98.33% for corn and 97.37% for wheat, and over 90% for rice and sugarcane. These come about to emphasize the adequacy of transfer learning in improving the model capacity to generalize over different plant infections, in this manner empowering more precise and dependable malady discovery. The suggestions of our discoveries amplify past scholastic intrigue, advertising down-to-earth arrangements for agriculturists and rural experts around the world, subsequently supporting economical rural homes in the confrontation of worldwide nourishment security challenges.
Author Keywords: Escalating;Detection;Transfer Learning;Scholastic;Intrigue;Nourishment
IEEE Terms: Precision agriculture;Plant diseases;Solid modeling;Biological system modeling;Transfer learning;Focusing;Crops

Document Title: MangoLeafViT: Leveraging Lightweight Vision Transformer with Runtime Augmentation for Efficient Mango Leaf Disease Classification
Authors: R. H. Chowdhury; S. Ahmed
Author Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Islamic University of Technology, Gazipur, Bangladesh; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Islamic University of Technology, Gazipur, Bangladesh
Publication Title: 2024 27th International Conference on Computer and Information Technology (ICCIT)
Abstract: Ensuring food safety is critical due to its profound impact on public health, economic stability, and global supply chains. Cultivation of Mango, a major agricultural product in several South Asian countries, faces high financial losses due to different diseases, affecting various aspects of the entire supply chain. While deep learning-based methods have been explored for mango leaf disease classification, there remains a gap in designing solutions that are computationally efficient and compatible with low-end devices. In this work, we propose a lightweight Vision Transformer-based pipeline with a self-attention mechanism to classify mango leaf diseases, achieving state-of-the-art performance with minimal computational overhead. Our approach leverages global attention to capture intricate patterns among disease types and incorporates runtime augmentation for enhanced performance. Evaluation on the MangoLeafBD dataset demonstrates a 99.43% accuracy, outperforming existing methods in terms of model size, parameter count, and FLOPs count.
Author Keywords: Lightweight models;MobileViT;Smart Agriculture;Transfer Learning;Food Safety;Attention Mechanism

Publication Title: 2023 Fourth International Conference on Smart Technologies in Computing, Electrical and Electronics (ICSTCEE)
Abstract: This article investigates the intricate interplay between artificial intelligence (AI) and development economics by analysing 1,484 articles from Elsevier's Scopus database. The study identifies China as the leading contributor in this field, followed by the United States and the United Kingdom, with India ranking fifth. Network analysis underscores AI's close connection to concepts like the circular economy, health economics, and ethics within development economics. Keywords such as machine learning, big data, deep learning, and sustainability indicate AI's rapid advancement. The article emphasises aligning AI with sustainable development goals, particularly in disaster management and ensuring an inclusive development model. Overcoming AI implementation challenges requires strategic government policies and social science input, addressing security, data privacy, and technology adoption at the grassroots level. In conclusion, well-governed advanced algorithms are poised to shape the future of global economics and contribute to realizing development objectives.
