Document Title: NanoDet-BiFPN: A Lightweight Wheat Ear Detection Network
Authors: X. Meng; Y. Wang; G. Yang; K. Zhang; Y. Zhang; W. Chen
Author Affiliations: College of Automation, Beijing Information Science and Technology University, Beijing, China; College of Automation, Beijing Information Science and Technology University, Beijing, China; College of Automation, Beijing Information Science and Technology University, Beijing, China; College of Automation, Beijing Information Science and Technology University, Beijing, China; College of Automation, Beijing Information Science and Technology University, Beijing, China; College of Automation, Beijing Information Science and Technology University, Beijing, China
Publication Title: 2024 8th Asian Conference on Artificial Intelligence Technology (ACAIT)
Abstract: Wheat, as a major staple crop extensively cultivated worldwide, supports the food needs of one-third of the global population. Its healthy cultivation not only concerns national food security but also profoundly affects the regulation and trade patterns of international food resources. To assess wheat planting density and predict yields, this study designs a lightweight wheat detection network based on NanoDet. The network encoding process incorporates Ghost convolution, which introduces more feature maps during the convolution process using fewer parameters and computing resources, thereby enhancing the network's computational efficiency and operational speed. Additionally, a Bidirectional Feature Pyramid Network (BiFPN) is employed to optimize the information transfer and fusion between feature layers, enhancing the model's capability to process multi-scale features, and further improving performance and efficiency. Experiments conducted on the public Global Wheat Head Dataset (GWHD) show that the model improves detection accuracy and speed without significantly increasing the size of the weight model file. The average detection precision of wheat heads reached 84.3%, with a detection speed of up to 14.3ms per frame, and the weight model file size is approximately 4.3MB. This rapid inference speed and minimal model size provide significant support for embedded devices, offering robust backing for the field application of intelligent agriculture.
Author Keywords: NanoDet;lightweight;wheat ear detection;intelligent agriculture
IEEE Terms: Smart agriculture;Visualization;Accuracy;Convolution;Computational modeling;Food security;Ear;Regulation;Nanoscale devices;Computational efficiency

Document Title: Novel approach for detecting Bacterial spot combining Transfer Learning and Large Language Models
Authors: Y. Tace; M. Tabaa; S. Elfilali; H. Bensag; C. Leghris
Author Affiliations: Laboratory of Information Technologies and Modelling, Faculty of Sciences Ben M’sik, Hassan II University, Casablanca, Morocco; Pluridisciplinary Laboratory of Research & Innovation (LPRI), EMSI, Casablanca, Morocco; Laboratory of Information Technologies and Modelling, Faculty of Sciences Ben M’sik, Hassan II University, Casablanca, Morocco; Pluridisciplinary Laboratory of Research & Innovation (LPRI), EMSI, Casablanca, Morocco; Computer Science Department, RTM Team, FST Mohammedia, HIIU, Casablanca, Morocco
Publication Title: 2024 IEEE 12th International Symposium on Signal, Image, Video and Communications (ISIVC)
Abstract: Bacterial spot, a pervasive disease affecting Solanaceae crops such as tomatoes and peppers, poses a significant threat to global food security and agricultural productivity. This paper presents a novel approach that integrates transfer learning techniques with Large Language Models (LLMs) to detect bacterial spot with high accuracy and efficiency. We employed state-of-the-art convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures, including Inception-V3 and MobileNet-V2, which were pre-trained on extensive image datasets and fine-tuned on a curated dataset comprising both PlantVillage images and in-house generated photographs from diverse agricultural settings. These images were further enhanced for model training through age and color classification, addressing the phenotypic variability inherent in real-world agricultural environments.The performance of the CNN models was rigorously evaluated, with Inception-V3 achieving a remarkable 97% accuracy in identifying bacterial spot, while the integration with LLMs provided critical insights into disease management strategies, effectively creating a multifaceted decision support system. The LLMs facilitated the interpretation of complex disease symptoms and treatment efficacy reports, enhancing the overall precision of the diagnostic process.Our research underscores the potential of combining transfer learning and LLMs to revolutionize plant disease detection and agricultural practices. This integrative approach not only advances the field of precision agriculture but also opens up new pathways for scalable, data-driven solutions to combat plant diseases and bolster crop health monitoring worldwide.
Author Keywords: Bacterial spot;LLMs;Transfer Learning;Plant diseases
IEEE Terms: Training;Productivity;Plant diseases;Microorganisms;Accuracy;Image color analysis;Transfer learning

Document Title: Onion Leaf Disease Classification Using Machine Learning Techniques
Authors: B. B. Vikhe; P. R. Patil; P. R. Bhaladhare; A. Potgantwar
Author Affiliations: School of Computer sciences and Engineering, Sandip University, Nashik; School of Computer sciences and Engineering, Sandip University, Nashik; School of Computer sciences and Engineering, Sandip University, Nashik; Sandip Institute of Technology and Research Centre, Nashik
Publication Title: 2024 2nd International Conference on Sustainable Computing and Smart Systems (ICSCSS)
Abstract: The onion, scientifically known as Allium cepa, is a fundamental food for agricultural labourers worldwide as well as people worldwide. Conversely, onion crops are susceptible to many illnesses that can greatly diminish their production. This article proposes a novel method for early detection of illnesses that damage onion leaves, utilising state-of-the-art machine learning techniques. Our collection comprises high-resolution images of onion leaves afflicted with various diseases such as downy mildew, bacterial blight, and purple blotch. By employing advanced convolutional neural networks (CNNs) such as ResNet50 and VGG16, which have been trained using transfer learning, our model can accurately detect diseases by extracting and categorizing visual input. Ensemble learning is more efficacious than data augmentation in enhancing predictions. Data augmentation expands the training dataset to enhance adaptability. In addition, the traditional methods such as support vector machines (SVM), decision trees, and random forests with convolutional neural networks (CNNs) are used. The results of the comparison show that the SVM algorithm is the most efficient and precise technique for diagnosing illnesses in onions leaves. Several commonly used metrics for evaluating model performance include the F1 score, recall, accuracy, and precision. The proposed method allows for non-intrusive continuous monitoring, empowering farmers to proactively mitigate the impact of diseases on onion harvests. This work contributes to the field of precision agriculture by applying machine learning techniques to enhance crop management in an effective and sustainable manner. This research study offers a comprehensive framework for promptly and accurately detecting onion leaf diseases, which achieves an essential need in the agricultural industry.
Author Keywords: Onion Leaves Classification;Disease Classification;Machine Learning Techniques

Document Title: Optimal Features Driven Attention Network With Medium-Scale Benchmark for Wheat Diseases Recognition
Authors: M. Islam; M. Aloraini; S. Habib; M. D. Alanazi; I. Khan; A. Khan
Author Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, College of Engineering, Qassim University, Buraydah, Saudi Arabia; Department of Electrical Engineering, College of Engineering, Qassim University, Buraydah, Saudi Arabia; Department of Information Technology, College of Computer, Qassim University, Buraydah, Saudi Arabia; Department of Electrical Engineering, College of Engineering, Jouf University, Sakaka, Saudi Arabia; Department of Computer Science, College of Computer and Information Sciences, Prince Sultan University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; Department of Botany, Islamia College University, Peshawar, Pakistan
Publication Title: IEEE Access
Abstract: Wheat serves as a crucial agricultural commodity and a primary dietary staple for numerous global populations. However, it faces persistent threats from various diseases targeting wheat leaves, ultimately impacting its production. Accurate and prompt automated disease diagnosis through advanced computer vision is crucial for safeguarding wheat quality. However, the literature relied on inadequate feature selection acquired from computationally expensive backbones followed by shallow layered networks. It is resultantly limiting their capacity to recognize and prioritize diseased areas effectively. Therefore, this paper introduces an optimal features-assisted lightweight framework that integrates EfficientNet-B3 with a spatial attention (SA) mechanism to capture healthy and unhealthy patterns effectively. The proposed framework harnesses this capability to address the vital regions affected by wheat diseases via an optimized, lightweight, and attentive network. Subsequently, we thoroughly analyzed several backbone features to identify robust hyperparameters conducive to achieving our lightweight objective. Furthermore, we employed SA blocks to fortify the network, directing attention efficiently towards diseased regions. The efficacy of the proposed network is validated through comprehensive evaluations conducted on both our proposed and LWDCD2020 benchmarks. Comparative analyses with existing methods consistently showcase superiority, firmly establishing our proposed approach as a viable network for wheat disease recognition. additionally, we also collected our own dataset, namely the Wheat Disease Five Classes Classification Dataset (WD5CC), and included diverse images.

Abstract: Data-driven digital agriculture relies on the ability to gather, process and understand information from field operations. In this context, raw data generated by farming equipment and machinery represents a fair share of the overall information that results from agricultural tasks and can be obtained even by older equipment after proper retrofit actions. This possibility shall, on the other hand, be handled and filtered to avoid that erroneous data might worsen the quality of a whole dataset. The aim of this research, performed on a narrow tractor in vineyard mechanised activities, was therefore to evaluate a method for splitting raw data gathered from the Controller Area Network (CAN) bus into different clusters corresponding to specific tasks that can be carried out on the field such as tillage, fertilisation, shredding, treatments, defoliation and harvest. As the data could be associated to a specific task, further data mining showed possible errors, biases, noise and particular pattern in the dataset. As a result, a refined dataset of vineyard operations has been produced, plus additional information regarding tractor paths and idle times has been provided. Further analysis could provide state of the art knowledge on narrow tractors operating costs for each type of field activity in real agricultural work contexts.

Publication Title: 2024 International Conference on Informatics, Multimedia, Cyber and Information System (ICIMCIS)
Abstract: This study focuses on optimizing GeoJSON data processing techniques in the Python environment to improve the performance of the On-board Computer Unit system (OBC) function used in precision fertilization in oil palm plantations. By integrating advanced data processing algorithms with OBC, this study can also improve the accuracy and efficiency of the Variable-Rate Fertilizer Application (VRFA) system. The GeoJSON format, known for its ability to represent geographic data, is used as the basis for representing detailed spatial map data from oil palm plantations. This optimized data is provided in the OBC unit, allowing for real-time adjustment of fertilizer applications based on specific conditions in the field. Experimental results show that GeoJSON data optimization in Python applied to OBC using Advanced RISC Machines (ARM) processors based on Reduced Instruction Set Computing (RISC) processor architecture significantly improves processing capabilities in terms of time efficiency when compared to Personal Computer (PC) applications using Intel processors based on Complex Instruction Set Computing (CISC) architecture by 13.41% for Nitrogen (N) macro elements, 27.67% for macro elements Phosphorus (P) and 32.77% for macro elements Potassium (K). So, it can be concluded that OBC computers with processor speed specifications almost similar to PCs offer a faster and more efficient solution for GeoJSON data processing time in precision agriculture.

G., India; International Institute of Information Technology (IIIT), Naya Raipur, C. G., India; Mahyco Private Limited, Maharashtra, India; Mahyco Private Limited, Maharashtra, India
Publication Title: TENCON 2024 - 2024 IEEE Region 10 Conference (TENCON)
Abstract: Accurate identification and counting of wheat heads are essential for reliable crop yield estimation. This study introduces a novel model, customized YOLOv8, specifically designed for wheat head detection in challenging agricultural environments using orthomosaic UAV imagery. Our end-to-end pipeline starts with orthomosaic images, identifying and extracting plots using YOLOv8, followed by plot tiling and detection on these tiles. The results are seamlessly stitched to reconstruct the original image with detected wheat heads. To enhance image quality-improving brightness, contrast, exposure, and reducing blur-Real ESR GAN was employed. Coupled with the Random Cut Out Method for occlusion handling, this significantly improved input image quality, facilitating accurate detection under challenging field conditions. Evaluation of the Mahycho dataset demonstrates promising results, with the model achieving a mean average precision (mAP) of 99.2% on plot detection and 83.4% accuracy on wheat head detection, surpassing existing benchmarks. The model exhibits robust performance under adverse conditions, maintaining high R2 values, and retains accuracy across different growth stages in field-collected datasets. Overall, the customized YOLOv8 model offers precise wheat head detection, advancing crop monitoring and management in real-world agricultural applications.

Abstract: Farmers are increasingly adopting Smart farming worldwide, leveraging various advanced technologies. Artificial Intelligence (AI) is instrumental in driving the evolution of smart agriculture applications. Internet of Things (IoT), edge computing, cloud computing, and big data are among the forefront technologies employed in this field. Agricultural activities typically encompass three phases: pre-harvest, during harvest, and postharvest. The pre-harvest phase involves choosing seeds, preparing the farm, and selecting the crops. Harvesting tasks include crop classification, disease analysis, and pathogen detection. Post-harvesting activities involve storage, cooling, and reaping, among others. This study conducted an in-depth review of activities in each phase, aiming at shortcomings related to AI-based Machine and Deep learning, IoT, security, datasets, and methodologies employed in existing research. This work also proposes a smart farming framework based on 6G technology, utilizing these identified research gaps. The main goal of this research is to improve agricultural technologies. The yield of crops is predicted with the help of K-means clustering algorithm and Improved Support Vector Machine which includes analysis of the fertility level of soil. Based on previously archived yield data that was obtained from that region, a projection was created. The systems analyze the data, and using pattern mining based on many characteristics, they forecast the crop production. Using data mining techniques, rules are formed for training data classification, and test data predictions are put into practice. To enhance soil fertility level prediction accuracy through the integration of a Hybrid I-SVM (Incremental Support Vector Machine) and K-means Clustering approach which demonstrates exceptional performance, achieving an impressive accuracy rate of 97.7%. Abstract: Mango leaf disease presents a significant challenge to mango trees worldwide, with untreated infections leading to severe leaf damage and potential tree mortality. Early detection is crucial to mitigating the effects of these diseases and preventing their spread. Our dataset includes 4,000 images categorized into eight classifications of mango leaf diseases, with 3,200 images for training and 800 for validation. This study employs a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) Transfer Learning Model, specifically ResNet50, trained with carefully tuned hyperparameters to achieve an accuracy of 97%. This innovative approach significantly reduces the time and effort required for traditional inspections, offering a precise and automated solution for disease detection. By improving diagnosis and supporting sustainable farming practices, this research contributes to the development of scalable solutions for managing mango crops effectively.

Abstract: Given the rapid increase in global population, advancements in agricultural technology are crucial for ensuring food security and promoting sustainable farming practices. The study suggests a new way to determine whether a farm is suitable for a given crop by combining several machine learning algorithms, namely Restricted Boltzmann Machines, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks (RBMs). Our objective is to combine these models so that we can better understand the patterns in agricultural data that are influenced by multiple variables, including weather, soil, crop yields, and other environmental factors. For the purpose of handling consecutive data and predicting future climatic trends that affect farming suitability, our long short-term memory (LSTM) model is designed. By expertly analysing patterns in satellite pictures and other spatial data, the CNN component assesses land qualities. Lastly, important factors influencing agricultural production are extracted using the RBM's feature learning abilities. Our integrated model was trained using a massive dataset collected from various agro-climatic zones. How well the model projected, given both present and future conditions, whether a plot of land would be appropriate for a specific crop was used to evaluate its effectiveness. The results demonstrate that our technique can reliably forecast which farms would be the best fit. Additionally, our model can assist lawmakers and farmers in making educated decisions regarding crop rotation, land usage, and operational management. A paradigm shift in precision agriculture could result from this. This research has the potential to improve crop yield, sustainability, and resilience to climate change by pushing the development of intelligent agricultural systems forward.

Publication Title: 2023 IEEE India Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium (InGARSS)
Abstract: Validation of satellite-derived surface reflectance (SR) or bottom of the atmosphere (BOA) products enhances the credibility for reliable resource monitoring and usability for a wide range of applications such as land cover mapping, forest monitoring, climate studies and precision agriculture. As satellite remote sensing continues to play a pivotal role in global environmental monitoring, accurate and traceable calibration/validation remains a critical component. This study presents a novel approach to the radiometric validation of surface reflectance products derived from Resourcesat-2(R2)/2A (RA) LISS3 sensor using RadCalNet (RCN) data, a comprehensive and high-quality ground-measured spectral radiance and reflectance dataset. By leveraging the spectral and radiometric information from RadCalNet and incorporating atmospheric correction, sensor-specific response functions and statistical techniques a traceable and accurate validation of SR products is established. SR products are well correlated with RCN-SR values having correlation coefficient value greater than 85% for R2 and greater than 94% for RA. Stability of SR values since launch was also evaluated with RCN measurements and found to be consistent. (Within 15 %(R2) and less than 10 %(RA)).

Abstract: In recent days, cold chain logistic progression has been affected due to covid quarantine because real-time human resources being affected. Agriculture transportation and food safety are essential for human lives to avoid wastage of product. Analyzing the stock hold management needs more prediction accuracy in the seasonal recommendations for producing Agri-products. Increasing information and collaborative approaches in big data leads to more dimensions to analyze the prediction leads to inaccuracy for a recommendation. To improve the cold chain process, intend a Real-time Cold chain forecasting model for agricultural logistic transportation using feature centric deep neural classification for a seasonal recommendation. Initially, the preprocess was carried out to reduce the noise present in the seasonal collective and cold chain logistic dataset, which contains information about agriculture in stock detail, production, seasonal, and daily requirement ratio. The cold chain recommendation big data analytics estimate the seasonal productive margin factor (SPMF) and Stock hold production hit rate (SPHR) for feature logistic margins. Then selects the features using Intensive Agro feature successive rate (IAFSR) be grouped into clusters. Then the selected features are trained with Multi-objective Deep sub spectral neural network (MODS2NN) to categorize the needs of classes for recommendation. This cold chain process improves the prediction accuracy as well than other methods to recommendation the logistic stock hold management by right seasonal recommendation.

Abstract: This study presents a novel approach for real-time tree row end detection in vineyards using a machine vision-based system leveraging the YOLOv8 object detection model. Addressing the limitations of GNSS technology in environments where signal obstruction is prevalent, this research aims to enhance the precision and reliability of autonomous navigation systems for electric vehicles (EVs) in agricultural settings. The developed system utilizes a dataset created from images captured using an HD camera mounted on the EV, encompassing various weather and canopy conditions to train the YOLOv8 model effectively. Real-time field experiments demonstrated the system's effectiveness, showing that the ‘End of row’ flag is accurately generated as the EV approaches the end of the vineyard row, with the initial distance measurement consistently falling within the 2.5-3 m range. This allows the EV to stop within the next 2–3 seconds at an optimal distance of approximately 1 m from the row end. This research highlights the potential of integrating advanced machine vision techniques with agricultural machinery, providing a robust alternative to traditional navigation aids in precision agriculture.

Abstract: In this study, a highly accurate classification system for potato leaves using Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) on the Plant Village dataset has been presented. The dataset comprises a diverse collection of potato leaf images, with annotations for healthy leaves and those affected by various diseases and stressors. Leveraging the temporal dependencies inherent in RNNs, it is aimed to effectively capture intricate patterns and features in sequential data, particularly crucial for time-series analysis of plant growth stages and disease progression. The proposed RNN architecture, incorporating long short-term memory (LSTM) units to address the vanishing gradient problem, demonstrated exceptional performance in accurately classifying potato leaf health, enabling early disease detection and timely interventions for improved crop management. Our study demonstrates the robustness and high accuracy of RNNs in classifying potato leaves, with performance metrics exceeding 92%. The integration of RNN-based classification systems into precision agriculture holds tremendous promise, providing farmers with valuable insights for timely interventions, optimizing crop health, and ensuring sustainable food production. From the experimental outcomes, it has been observed that the “RNN Model“ records the highest accuracy of 0.927, which is a higher value compared to the “CNN (Convolution neural network) Model“ (0.902) and the “Feedforward neural network“ (0.867). The success of proposed DL model in agricultural applications illustrates the transformative potential of AI technologies in addressing global food security challenges and revolutionizing the future of agriculture.

Document Title: Reimagining Cucumber Disease Diagnosis in the Era of Federated Learning CNN
Authors: Y. Nagpal; V. Kukreja; S. Mehta; A. Jain; A. Choudhury
Author Affiliations: Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, India; Computer Science and Engineering, Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, India
Publication Title: 2023 4th IEEE Global Conference for Advancement in Technology (GCAT)
Abstract: Early identification of plant diseases is crucial for guaranteeing sustainable agricultural methods and improving yields in the constantly changing field of precision agriculture. This study attempts to examine the identification of six different groups of illnesses that affect cucumber leaves. The use of federated learning, a decentralized machine learning paradigm, combined data from four other clients while preserving the privacy and effectiveness of the data. The model’s design included a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to improve diagnostic skills. Federated Learning and CNN thoroughly examined the four customers’ local data. The findings showed that client accuracy varied, with a clear development in model performance: Client 1 had an average accuracy of 84.85%, Client 2 had a score of 90.23%, Client 3 had a score of 91.77%, and Client 4 had a score of 91.59%. These findings highlight the federated learning paradigm’s flexibility and promise for managing a variety of distributed datasets. The research also highlighted the use of federated averaging to combine local findings into a comprehensive global model. The results were enlightening when examined through the lenses of Macro, Micro, and Weighted Averages: The weighted average traced a trajectory from 86.79% to 91.92%, while the micro-average followed the weighted average, starting at 86.71% and ending at 91.92%. The macro-average accuracy trended from 84.88% to 91.60%. These nuanced insights highlighted the model’s accuracy across many average measures, which also underscored the model’s robustness in potentially unbalanced datasets. In conclusion, this study supports using CNNs with federated learning to identify illnesses in cucumber leaves.
Author Keywords: Cucumber leaves;Leaf diseases;Convolutional Neural Network (CNN);Federated learning (FL);Disease Classification

According to the analysis of actual project development and application, the architecture and simulation algorithm of distributed virtual laboratory are the focus of current research. From the perspective of practical application, it can be seen that the effective communication between Client/Server mode and TCP/IP protocol, the Client in the local database and the Server in the global database, can not only control the response time of the system, but also improve the overall execution efficiency under the guidance of multi-threading technology. Document Title: SMART FARMING SYSTEM: Enhancing Water Efficiency, Automated Care, and Disease Detection Using IoT and CNN

Abstract: The International Water Management Institute states that because of insufficient or excessive water supplies, inefficient irrigation techniques can result in crop output reductions of up to 30%. Inadequate irrigation practices can lead to waterlogging and salt problems on up to 25% of the irrigated land area worldwide. In addition to automatic watering, this study presents a smart farming system designed specifically for Neon Pothos that uses convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for disease detection and real-time monitoring. Neon Pothos' specific requirements are met by the system for this experimental procedure, which makes use of a NodeMCU ESP-12E (8266) microprocessor, a high-precision moisture sensor, and a DHT22 temperature/humidity sensor. CNN makes problem identification simple and efficient to identify diseases. Through a dashboard on a mobile application, users may keep an eye on various parameters and receive push notifications for illness and irrigation alerts. Ad hoc watering is made possible via manual pump control, and powerful algorithms that use the system's database to analyze disease prevalence and water use improve watering plans. This system, which combines technology, algorithms, and user-centered design to promote sustainable farming habits, helps preserve water resources and promotes environmental health.

Abstract: One of the purposes of smart agriculture is to predict the yield of paddy rice using agricultural data using machine learning. LightGBM, one of the machine learning algorithms, is applied to the yield prediction problem of paddy rice in this paper. Since LightGBM has a large number of hyperparameters, the hyperparameter optimization using the stochastic schemata exploiter (SSE) is used. From the results of comparison with Genetic Algorithm (GA), it is confirmed that SSE has a fast convergence speed. In addition, it is found that the higher the mutation rate of SSE, the more converged to the global optimal solution without falling into the local solution.

Document Title: Segment Anything Model (SAM) Applications: Coffee Rust Detection with Image Processing
Authors: B. Vides-Flores; E. Martinez-Ramirez; Y. Rodriguez-Gallo
Author Affiliations: Faculty of Aeronautics, Don Bosco University, San Salvador, EI Salvador; Faculty of Electronics, Don Bosco University, San Salvador, El Salvador; Faculty of Electronics, Don Bosco University, San Salvador, El Salvador
Publication Title: 2024 IEEE Central America and Panama Student Conference (CONESCAPAN)
Abstract: Coffee Leaf Rust (CLR) poses a significant threat to coffee production worldwide, with the potential to cause substantial yield reductions in severe cases. Early detection of such diseases is crucial to mitigate severe damage and economic losses. Addressing this issue requires precise and efficient detection methods. This paper explores the development of two algorithms for detecting CLR in coffee leaves using the RoCoLe and BRACOL datasets. The first algorithm, termed exclusive SAM, relies solely on the Segment Anything Model (SAM), while the second algorithm, termed SAM Assisted, uses SAM in conjunction with additional image processing techniques. The results demonstrate that the exclusive SAM algorithm achieves an accuracy of 92% on the RoCoLe dataset and 88% on the BRACOL dataset. In contrast, the SAM Assisted algorithm achieves an accuracy of 94% with the RoCoLe dataset and 96% with the BRACOL dataset. Lastly, this research identified the difficulties the Segment Anything Model (SAM) faces when performing specialized segmentation tasks on its own. However, it also highlighted SAM's potential as a supporting tool for more robust algorithms. In the future, this will likely be the most important role of SAM in precision agriculture research. Additionally, the second algorithm developed using SAM showed very promising results with image techniques not conventionally used in agricultural applications, warranting further investigation.
Author Keywords: Artificial Intelligence;coffee leaf rust;image processing;SAM
IEEE Terms: Precision agriculture;Image segmentation;Deconvolution;Costs;Computational modeling;Process control;Real-time systems;Faces;Context modeling;Diseases

Author Affiliations: VISIE Ltd., Dhaka, Bangladesh; VISIE Ltd., Dhaka, Bangladesh; NA; Computer Science and Engineering Department, Khulna University of Engineering & Technology, Khulna, Bangladesh; ICT Cell, Khulna University, Khulna, Bangladesh; Computer Science and Engineering Department, Ahsanullah University of Science and Technology, Dhaka, Bangladesh; VISIE Ltd., Dhaka, Bangladesh
Publication Title: 2024 27th International Conference on Computer and Information Technology (ICCIT)
Abstract: Potato crops, vital to global food security, are often jeopardized by numerous foliar diseases, including late blight, early blight, and bacterial leaf spot. If untreated, these illnesses can lead to substantial yield losses and negatively impact agricultural output. Conventional disease diagnosis methods, which frequently depend on expert manual inspection, are both time-consuming and labor-intensive, as well as prone to human errors. Recent improvements in deep learning-based image classification approaches have shown considerable potential in automating the identification of plant diseases, offering a scalable and more dependable alternative to manual inspections. In this research, we proposed a Self-Supervised Contrastive Learning methodology for the classification of potato leaf diseases using two publicly available potato leaf datasets. Our model attained an accuracy of 99.46% with a loss of 0.013957 and an accuracy of 98.79% with a loss of 0.096844. These results indicate the potential of self-supervised contrastive learning in agricultural disease detection, offering a scalable and efficient solution for real-world disease classification with minimal reliance on labeled data.

Abstract: In light of the pressing need to guarantee food security in the face of threats posed by climate change, an increasing global population together with rising incomes, worsening soil erosion, and dwindling water resources, crop yield forecasting has assumed more significance in recent years. A relatively new area of study, “Explainable AI” seeks to provide context for the findings produced by Deep learning models. Nevertheless, there is a pressing need for more comprehensive evaluations of deep learning models for object classification in images. Due to this, the research suggests two steps for implementing Explainable AI: (1) assessing the deep-learning(DL)-strategies accuracy utilizing evaluation methods, and (2) evaluating the feature recognition skill of an scan when recognized by DL utilizing Grad-CAM for model construal. Compared to EfficientNetV2S and Xception, the results reveal that MobieNet model has lower dependability but higher accuracy. When taking the ratio match rate into account, though, MobileNetV2 achieves the best accuracy. Building intelligent agriculture support systems (with the help of automated fruit-picking robots that discard bad fruits) is one application of the study's findings. Another is the utilization of the Explainable AI model's output to determine the best deep learning model for processing.

Abstract: This research explores the challenge of incorporating IoT with Machine Learning (ML) applications to Precision Agriculture, particularly the use of wireless sensors for irrigation control. Information from sensors that monitor key parameters including temperature, humidity, moisture, and water levels are used to forecast water requirements and control pumps. Support vector machine (SVM), Decision tree (DT), Random Forest (RF) and Naïve Bayes (NB) techniques are adopted for the analysis to find out their accuracy levels. It is observed from all the above-performed models that among all, the SVM has the maximum prediction rate of the given dataset and is slightly outperformed by only the DT and RF. The confusion matrix which points to the misclassification patterns of each model gives an insight into identifying the best ML approach for use. The convergence of IoT and ML guarantees flexibility and responsiveness when controlling and designing agricultural systems. It is this approach that has the potential to enhance water resources management as well as address issues precipitated by climate change and growing worldwide food demand.

Abstract: Rice, being recognized as a fundamental staple crop on a global scale, assumes a central position in ensuring food security worldwide. Nevertheless the agricultural sector encounters significant obstacles in the shape of many illnesses that possess the potential to cause severe damage to crop productivity and jeopardize the availability of food resources. The proposed work endeavors to undertake a thorough investigation to tackle these issues by creating a resilient system for detecting diseases and classifying rice plants into multiple categories. Rice farming is faced with several frequent illnesses, each possessing distinct characteristics and exerting a specific impact on the health of the crop. The diseases encompassing rice blast, rice blight, hispa disease, and rice stem rot disease are widely recognized for their significant capacity to case extensive harm. Differentiating these illnesses from healthy rice plants is a procedure that requires significant labor and is susceptible to errors when conducted manually. To address these problems, the suggested study has carefully assembled a dataset consisting of high-resolution photos of rice plants. These images encompass a range of growth phases and indications of diseases. By utilizing state-of-the-art deep learning (DL) methodologies, the proposed work developed an advanced image processing model that exhibits the ability to classify rice plants into five discrete categories: healthy, rice blast, rice blight, hispa disease, and rice stem rot disease, without the need for manual intervention. The presented research encompasses not only the construction of a precise classification model but also explores the practical consequences of early illness detection in the context of rice farming. The experimental findings yielded highly encouraging results, as our model had an exceptional accuracy rate of 97.21%. The practical implications of our research extend far beyond the boundaries of the laboratory. The implementation of precision agricultural techniques is crucial for the promotion of sustainable rice cultivation and the maintenance of food security in an era characterized by significant global transformations.

Abstract: Sri Lanka is a global hub for tea production worldwide, and the tea industry has enormous economic and cultural significance to the country. However, the tea industry, though, is confronted with numerous challenges, including unpredictable weather conditions, improper fertilizer application, pest and disease outbreaks, and suboptimal cultivation practices. These challenges are leading to lower yield and more losses. With the increasing unpredictability of weather patterns, it is challenging to determine the precise fertilizer application schedule and dosage. In terms of pest and diseases, effect of the Shot-hole borer, Tea Blister Blight and Stem and Branch Canker are more destructive to the tea plant. Therefore, accurate weather prediction and the early detection of those infections are crucial tasks in tea cultivation. This study presents a smart monitoring system for Sri Lankan tea crop that combines IoT, image processing, audio processing, and DL technologies to address such problems. The Smart Monitoring System gives growers a full toolkit by providing real-time weather insights, fertilizer delivery depending on weather conditions, early insect detection, disease identification, and damage quantification. According to performance evaluations, the proposed method's accuracy results for weather prediction, fertilizer application and identifications of disease, pest, deficiency, and degree of diseased conditions are in the range of 80-100%.

In this project, the aim is to develop a deep learning model which will predict an individual farm’s crop yield using remotely sensed satellite images. The study focuses on crop yield estimation of wheat, corn and soybean in the chosen study area in KBS-LIER, Michigan, United States. Four vegetative spectral indices, including NDVI and SAVI, etc. were calculated from the seven spectral bands collected over 11 years. Abstract: This paper introduces a versatile multi-sensor carrier platform designed for multi-seasonal data collection in modern commercial fruit growing, developed to address the challenges associated with data acquisition in this field. The platform ensures reliable power supply, integrates precise geo-referencing using RTK-GNSS, and provides an intuitive user interface, allowing non-technical personnel to conduct field data collection efficiently. A specific variant of the multi-sensor system is equipped with high-quality sensors to capture high-resolution RGB images, LiDAR point clouds and IMU data, enabling the recording of recurring datasets throughout and across the season. The platform holds significant potential for enhancing the efficiency and accuracy of treatment measures in fruit growing by incorporating deep learning algorithms and utilizing historical datasets for multi-seasonal predictive models. Further research is focused on advancing the data flow concept to integrate manual assessment data from experts with RGB images based on RTK-GNSS positions for each individual tree. This work represents a significant step towards improving data-driven decision-making in commercial fruit growing. A bloom dataset is released to demonstrate the system's capabilities and provide researchers access to valuable data (http://dx.doi.org/10.24406/fordatis/367).

Abstract: The fungus Blumeriella jaapii is responsible for a widespread disease known as cherry leaf spot (CLS). This affects the productivity and economic prospects of cherry orchards worldwide. CLS, a complex beast with far-reaching implications for crops’ yield and fruit quality, requires comprehensive treatments. The proposed study novel hybrid model that creatively combines the benefits of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and XGBoost. This breakthrough offers an entirely new concept for automated plant disease detection research. But fundamentally, this study is based on a dataset built very carefully--there are 7500 high-resolution images from many orchards that were painstakingly collected and contributed. This rich dataset becomes the ground on which our hybrid model paints its masterly portrait of disease-discriminating prowess. This model has an impressive overall accuracy of 98.67%, which represents a breakthrough in plant disease diagnosis by robots. By departing from the precision, recall, and F1-score metrics, this then provides a deeper level of analysis that breaks down in more granular terms how effective the model is. Furthermore, it allows you to discern between CLS at different magnitudes as well. The Confusion Matrix is like an unfolding narrative itself. It depicts the finer points of model performance and reveals where it needs to be strengthened for training to be more relevant. One special feature of our approach involves the comparative analysis of collaborations between CNN and XGBoost.

Abstract: This paper investigates the application of Few Shot Segmentation techniques in addressing weed management challenges within agricultural robotics. Traditional methods, such as indiscriminate herbicide spraying, pose environmental and economic concerns, emphasize the necessity of developing automated precision procedures. Semantic Segmentation models can offer significant advancements in weed management within agricultural robotics but can be negatively impacted by domain shifts, often requiring adaptation, hindering the development of the field. In this context, we propose a Few Shot Segmentation-based approach for precise weed segmentation in corn and bean cultivations. Our model, adapted from PFENet, exhibits robust performance across varying environmental conditions, mitigating domain shift issues. Evaluation on the ROSE dataset demonstrates the model’s reliability and generalizability, highlighting the potential of Few Shot Segmentation in advancing agricultural robotics technologies.

The research analyzed a dataset from apple orchards collected in 2020. By examining these data points, we sought to derive critical insights, including individual tree segmentation and canopy density mapping. The work unfolds in two main phases. Author Affiliations: Department of Soil Science, University of São Paulo, Piracicaba, Brazil; Department of Remote sensing and Geographical Information System, Federal University of Technology, Akure, Nigeria; Department of Environmental Management, Federal University of Technology, Owerri, Nigeria; Spatial and Data science society of Nigeria, Abuja, Nigeria; Department of Electronic Engineering, Federal University of Technology, Owerri, Nigeria; Department of Surveying & Geoinformatics, Federal University of Technology, Owerri, Nigeria; Department of Environmental Management, Federal University of Technology, Owerri, Nigeria; Department of Environmental Management, Federal University of Technology, Owerri, Nigeria; Department of Environmental Management, Federal University of Technology, Owerri, Nigeria; Department of Geography, Federal University, Lafia, Nigeria; Department of Remote sensing and Geographical Information System, Federal University of Technology, Akure, Nigeria; Department of Soil Science, University of São Paulo, Piracicaba, Brazil; Department of Biology, Federal University of Technology, Owerri, Nigeria; Department of Geography and Environmental management, Imo State University, Owerri, Nigeria; Department of Geography and Environmental management, Imo State University, Owerri, Nigeria
Publication Title: 2024 IEEE International Conference on Agrosystem Engineering, Technology & Applications (AGRETA)
Abstract: Soil organic carbon (SOC) is an indispensable component in the global terrestrial carbon store that might be influenced by land use, and environmental factors. As a famous food production State in Brazil, there have been intensive agricultural activities in Mato Grosso State. The conversion of pasture to croplands has influenced the accumulation and distribution of SOC stocks in the State. This work aimed at determining the spatial variations in SOC stocks and its relationship with land use and environmental drivers in Mato Grosso, a high agricultural frontier State of Brazil. Data containing SOC content at the topsoil layer (0-30cm), land use, and environmental indicators data were collected and analyzed from both field and secondary sources including satellite images. The results revealed that SOC stores were higher in croplands (especially with dual or multi-crops) when compared with forests, pasture, and other land use. It was further observed that SOC had a positive correlation with land use (r = 0.64), elevation (r = 0.56), rainfall (r = 0.39), normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) (r = 0.40), bare soil index (BSI) (r = 0.40), and land surface temperature (LST) (r = 0.39). The adoption of low-carbon farming (such as crop-livestock forest, integrated crop-livestock, agroforestry, and other conservational agricultural practices) in Mato Grosso has crucial role in providing sustainable environmental and economic development of Mato Grosso, Brazil, and other regions. Thus, agricultural agendas focusing on climate-smart farming should be incorporated into the government's policy making schemes. This would ensure food security, and in the long-term help to mitigate climate change by eliminating excess atmospheric CO2 and converting it into sequestrated SOC.
Author Keywords: Climate-smart agriculture;carbon sequestration;land use;climate change;Mato Grosso State
IEEE Terms: Climate change;Forests;Normalized difference vegetation index;Rain;Soil;Agriculture;Land surface temperature;Carbon;Remote sensing;Farming

Document Title: Transfer Learning Based Crop Disease Identification Using State-of-the-art Deep Learning Framework
Authors: G. Kang; J. Wang; X. Yue; G. Zeng; Z. Feng
Author Affiliations: South China Agriculture University, Guangzhou, Guangdong, China; Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Daytona Beach, FL, USA; South China Agriculture University, Guangzhou, Guangdong, China; South China Agriculture University, Guangzhou, Guangdong, China; South China Agriculture University, Guangzhou, Guangdong, China
Publication Title: 2021 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
Abstract: Agriculture production plays a crucial role in the growth of the world’s economy. However, technologies and innovations in the Precision Agriculture (PA) domain are still in their infancy. Typically, the problem of incorrect identification of crop disease still remains unsolved, thus causes agricultural production losses worldwide. To solve this problem, we apply transfer learning based Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to identify different diseases of the crops. Specifically, this study focuses on evaluating the identification performance of the four state-of-the-art deep learning architectures: Residual Network (ResNet), MobileNet GoogLeNet and AlexNet. The PlantVillage dataset used in this study is made publicly available for academic study at Kaggle repository, which consists of 54,323 images of 38 kinds of crop diseases, and 14 kinds of crop diseases from them are derived as dataset for this study. By applying transfer learning, we make a comprehensive performance comparison among the implemented architectures, and evaluation results show that the MobileNet performs better in identifying crop disease, achieving an accuracy of 99.27%, followed by the GoogLeNet achieving an accuracy of 99.14%, AlexNet achieving an accuracy of 97.92%, and ResNet achieving an accuracy of 97.03%. Experiment results in this study prove the effectiveness of transfer learning based CNN models in crop disease identification, as well as provide a guidance on choosing an appropriate network to identify different crop diseases.
IEEE Terms: Deep learning;Training;Biological system modeling;Transfer learning;Crops;Production;Computer architecture

Document Title: Transformative Technology in Poultry Management: 3D CNNs for Broiler Chicken Weight Prediction
Authors: A. K; V. K. Kaliappan; G. Baniekal Hiremath
Author Affiliations: Department of Computer Science Engineering, KPR Institute of Engineering and Technology, Coimbatore, Tamilnadu, India; Department of Computer Science Engineering, KPR Institute of Engineering and Technology, Coimbatore, Tamilnadu, India; Wasp Autonomous Systems Pvt Ltd, Ballari, Karnataka, India
Publication Title: 2024 International Conference on Cognitive Robotics and Intelligent Systems (ICC - ROBINS)
Abstract: In global food production, broiler chickens hold significant importance, which are traditionally managed through manual labour for both meat and egg production. However, the poultry farming industry has increasingly turned to automation to address challenges associated with manual labour and enhance efficiency. This research introduces a novel methodology for estimating chicken weight utilizing top-view videos as input and leveraging 3D Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). Accurate weight assessment is a critical aspect of poultry farming, influencing feeding strategies and resource allocation. Traditional manual weighing methods are laborious and time-intensive, necessitating the exploration of automated alternatives. The methodology involves dataset collection, preprocessing, and employing 3D CNNs for effective feature extraction. 3D CNN architecture, adept at capturing spatial and temporal features, consists of convolutional and pooling layers, followed by flatten and dense layers for weight prediction. The model achieves a remarkable accuracy of 95%, as evidenced in the experimental results. Experimental validation showcases the potential of this method as a non-invasive and efficient tool for estimating chicken weight. It contributes to the growing field of automated livestock management in agriculture.
Author Keywords: 3D CNN;Deep learning;Preprocessing;3D-CNN;Model Evaluation
IEEE Terms: Three-dimensional displays;Sociology;Production;Manuals;Feature extraction;Robustness;Convolutional neural networks

Marconi, University of Bologna, Bologna, Italy
Publication Title: 2024 IEEE International Workshop on Metrology for Agriculture and Forestry (MetroAgriFor)
Abstract: In the context of Precision Agriculture, the importance of an effective information management system is crucial to enable the required accuracy and efficiency of tasks. Increasing the resolution of maps can improve this, up to reach the plant-based level, or even distinguish different parts or zones of the single tree. Therefore, plant/tree recognition became of paramount importance when adjusting inputs or estimating physiological properties. The research activities at the Cadriano experimental station of the University of Bologna are going towards this direction. In this paper, the monitoring system under development within the university research group is presented, describing the data collection hardware and software framework, together with the first preliminary applications and analysis coming from the system. The whole architecture exploits both the robotic platform present on site, the in-situ sensors scattered on different orchards and fields and traditional manual measurements to create a global homogeneous database that will serve as the foundation of upcoming research activities.

Document Title: Turmeric leaf disease detection using optimized deep learning model
Authors: R. Selvaraj; M. S. G. Devasena; T. Satheesh; K. Karpagavadivu; F. Ravindaran
Author Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Dr.N.G.P. Institute of Technology, Coimbatore, India; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Sri Ramakrishna Engineering College, Coimbatore, India; Department of Artificial Intelligence and Data Science, Dr.N.G.P. Institute of Technology, Coimbatore, India; Department of Artificial Intelligence and Data Science, Dr.N.G.P. Institute of Technology, Coimbatore, India; Computer Science and Engineering (Cyber Security), Karpagam college of Engineering, Coimbatore, India
Publication Title: 2nd International Conference on Computer Vision and Internet of Things (ICCVIoT 2024)
Abstract: Turmeric is popular for its medicinal, culinary, and non-culinary uses. Turmeric cultivation is affected due to disease in their leaves. Farmers conventionally identify the leaf diseases and provide pesticides to avoid further loss. However, manual identification of leaf disease over large farms is time-consuming and requires human effort. Also, in several types of leaf disease, the specific type that occurs in the plant should be distinguished; thus, proper knowledge of farming is required. To simplify this and to know the type of disease, smart agricultural practices are followed worldwide. One of the intelligent techniques adopted in farming is leaf disease detection. By providing the filed image to a learning algorithm, the type of disease can be detected accurately without manual interventions. ML and DL are used in this smart agricultural practice. To improve the performance further, an optimized deep learning model is presented in this research work. A Novel gazelle optimization algorithm is combined with deep learning MobileNetV3 network to attain enhanced disease detection performance. Experimentation on our own dataset with 5000 samples, including leaf spot, leaf blight, leaf rot, and curl disease-affected leaves, the proposed model performance is evaluated and observed with a maximum accuracy of 96.8%, a precision of 97.1% over conventional disease detection models.

Document Title: Using AI and IoT at the Edge of the network
Authors: S. Lakrouni; M. Sebgui; S. Bah
Author Affiliations: Smart Communication Research Team, Mohamedia School of Engineers, University Mohammed V in Rabat, Morocco; Smart Communication Research Team, Mohamedia School of Engineers, University Mohammed V in Rabat, Morocco; Smart Communication Research Team, Mohamedia School of Engineers, University Mohammed V in Rabat, Morocco
Publication Title: 2022 8th International Conference on Optimization and Applications (ICOA)
Abstract: In recent years, IoT devices have been widely used in a variety of sectors such as industry, smart farming, and smart homes. Its application requires performing high computational analysis in real-time. The research era of Artificial Intelligence has witnessed an intense development conducted by millions of research and applications that extend from systems recommendation to video/audio surveillance. AI algorithms have been deployed to IoT data to bring intelligent decisions for IoT applications. These numerous data increase the time of the data transition to the cloud, which becomes the bottleneck of the cloud-based architecture. The edge computing technology brings the AI algorithms to the Edge of the network to improve latency, bandwidth, and data privacy, and guarantee the high accuracy of the AI algorithms. Recently Federated learning (FL) is a machine learning technique that distributes the training among edge devices near to the data source in light of increasing privacy and leveraging from the massive data distributed among numerous edge devices. Therefore, in this paper, we introduce recent research that demonstrates the effectiveness of this approach and present the architectures, models, and methods that implement FL with IoT devices.
Author Keywords: Edge Computing;Artificial Intelligence;Federated Learning
IEEE Terms: Training;Performance evaluation;Data privacy;Machine learning algorithms;Distributed databases;Computer architecture;Bandwidth

Document Title: Using Deep Learning for Precise Plant Pathology Diagnosis in the field of Agriculture
Authors: P. Kaushik; K. S. Gill; N. Thapliyal; R. S. Rawat
Author Affiliations: Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Chitkara University Institute of Engineering and Technology, Chitkara University, Punjab, India; Computer Science & Engineering, Graphic Era Hill University, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, India; Computer Science & Engineering, Graphic Era Deemed to be University, Dehradun, Uttarakhand, India
Publication Title: 2024 IEEE International Conference on Smart Power Control and Renewable Energy (ICSPCRE)
Abstract: Plant diseases are posing an increasing danger to the global food supply, which indicates that we truly need more precise and advanced methods of disease detection. This work aims to address this issue by use of cutting edge deep learning technologies. The paper examines how effectively various models identify plant diseases. Among the models it examines are VGG13, Squeezenet1_1, ResNet34, Inception_ v3, and DenseNet169. Information utilized includes a baseline class from the DAGS dataset and 38 distinct plant diseases from the PlantVillage dataset that was taken from Kaggle. The findings indicate that various designs and training methods function somewhat differently. AlexNet, for instance, reaches 99.24% accuracy after extensive retraining. When DenseNet169 is deep retrained, however, it does incredibly well, achieving 99.72% accuracy. To better comprehend the behavior of the models, the study involves visualization experiments in addition to accuracy measurements. Heat maps that graphically illustrate how various aspects of a picture impact the choices the computer program makes are displayed in the occlusion experiment. The saliency map experiment determines the most significant pixels using mathematical means. This clarifies the ways in which the model draws judgments. With AlexNet and VGG13, images of several plant diseases like Early Blight, Late Blight, and Septoria Leaf Spot are displayed. In conclusion, this paper presents key details concerning the operation of many deep learning models for identifying plant diseases. The outcomes facilitate the selection of the optimal models and training programs, therefore enhancing the development of reliable and robust automated systems for plant disease diagnosis. Using the newest technologies, this research is a crucial first step in introducing sophisticated disease detection to agriculture.
Author Keywords: Deep Learning;Plant Disease Detection;Convolutional Neural Networks;Occlusion Experiment;Saliency Map;PyTorch;Model Visualization;Interpretability;Agriculture
IEEE Terms: Deep learning;Training;Plant diseases;Visualization;Pathology;Accuracy;Computational modeling

Document Title: VisionaryX-9: Efficient plant disease prediction model
Authors: I. S. Rajput; K. Bhardwaj; D. Sanwal
Author Affiliations: CSE Department, Grahpic Era Hill University, Haldwani; CSE Department, Grahpic Era Hill University, Haldwani; CSE Department, Grahpic Era Hill University, Haldwani
Publication Title: 2024 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Computing and Signal Processing (IICCCS)
Abstract: Agriculture, which is the foundation of worldwide sustenance, is facing substantial obstacles in the twenty-first century, mainly because of increasing demands for food production and the growing menace of plant diseases. Ensuring the well-being of crops is of utmost importance for the security of global food supply, which requires the timely and precise detection of plant diseases. Conventional approaches are becoming less effective in dealing with the changing agricultural dangers, necessitating the development of new and creative solutions. The incorporation of machine learning and deep learning technologies in recent agricultural practices has significantly transformed plant disease diagnosis, providing remarkable levels of accuracy, efficiency, and scalability. This study utilises advanced algorithms such as ResNet, VGG, and EfficientNet to improve the accuracy of disease identification, thereby revolutionising precision agriculture. The main objective of this article is to enhance the process of plant disease detection with the help of a sophisticated model, VisonaryX-9, that can not only properly identify plant diseases but also classify their symptoms. The objective is to empower farmers by furnishing them with timely information, enabling informed decisions that directly influence agricultural output and, consequently, global food production. Our contributions consist of the creation of VisonaryX-9, a hybrid model that merges the ResNet and VGG architectures. The model is validated with a dataset of having 87,295 real-world plant disease images. The results obtained indicates the the model outperforms other baseline model with an accuracy of 99.12%. Our objective is to reveal profound understandings that will enhance the discussion on sustainable and resilient farming methodologies.
Author Keywords: Plant disease detection;Deep Learning;Machine Learning;Disease Prediction;VisionaryX-9
IEEE Terms: Plant diseases;Accuracy;Food manufacturing;Computational modeling;Scalability;Signal processing algorithms;Signal processing;Predictive models;Telecommunication computing;Security

Document Title: Wheat Leaf Disease Detection Using CapsNet in Agri-Tech
Authors: N. Subash; S. Sushanth; T. S. Shivani; P. Sooraj
Author Affiliations: Department of ECE VNR VJIET, Hyderabad, India; Department of ECE VNR VJIET, Hyderabad, India; Department of ECE VNR VJIET, Hyderabad, India; Department of ECE VNR VJIET, Hyderabad, India
Publication Title: 2024 2nd International Conference on Cyber Physical Systems, Power Electronics and Electric Vehicles (ICPEEV)
Abstract: Various diseases that affect the growth of wheat are important threats to food security in the world. This project aims at developing a system of wheat diseases diagnosis based on the integration of CapsNet into IoT. This dataset includes the images of different types of wheat diseases to include STB, stem rust, Septoria, tannin spot and powdery mildew, that affects Tunisia. Pre-processing and data augmentation bring in conformity to methods of training and improving the non uniformity and a diversified type of the dataset. CapsNet also has the feature called affiliative invariance which helps to solve the problem of varying camera angles and increases the model's accuracy. Even deeper capabilities can be achieved in transfer learning within hyperparameter tuning of the pre-trained CapsNets models. Applications of IoT empowers a continuous monitoring of the disease that affects crops, extensive and efficient spraying of biopesticides in agriculture. Wheat grains that are transformed into sensors are able to track changes in their environment; on the other hand, cameras of specific functions capture image data. Prompts and advisories from time to time assist farmers in preventing such challenges; hence, enhancing the productions and qualities. This work is helpful to agricultural in general and more specifically it is a supplement to the process of crop health monitoring and early signs of diseases detection, thus being a boost to global food security.
Author Keywords: Wheat disease identification;Convolutional Capsules Sensor Network;Precision agriculture;Image analysis;Multi-category classification;Deep Learning;Data pre-processing;Data augmentation;Fine-tuning of hyper-parameters;Non-invasive crop condition diagnosis;Real-time notification;Organism-based sustainable agriculture;Food security
IEEE Terms: Deep learning;Training;Image sensors;Biological system modeling;Food security;Crops;Data augmentation;Cameras;Sensors;Diseases

Document Title: YOLOv8 Lightweight Crop Disease Detection
Authors: Y. Gao; H. Peng; X. Li; A. Gao
Author Affiliations: Intelligent Manufacturing Institute, Jianghan University, Wuhan, China; Intelligent Manufacturing Institute, Jianghan University, Wuhan, China; Intelligent Manufacturing Institute, Jianghan University, Wuhan, China; Intelligent Manufacturing Institute, Jianghan University, Wuhan, China
Publication Title: 2024 3rd International Conference on Advanced Sensing, Intelligent Manufacturing (ASIM)
Abstract: To address the problems of large algorithm parameters, slow calculation speed and insufficient public datasets in crop disease recognition, this paper proposes an improved target detection algorithm YOLOv8-self based on YOLOv8. First, the Mydataset crop disease dataset is created, which contains 12 common diseases, making up for the shortcomings of the dataset. Secondly, a lightweight module Faster Neural Networks is introduced to reduce the model parameters and calculation amount significantly; Bi-directional Feature Pyramid Network is used to improve the feature fusion efficiency and further reduce the number of parameters; and Deformable Large Kernel Conv is used to expand the receptive field, strengthen global feature capture and local feature extraction. Experiments are conducted on three datasets: Mydataset, VOC-2007 and Vehicles. The results show that compared with the original YOLOv8, YOLOv8-self reduces the number of parameters by 20.3% on the Mydataset dataset, increases mAP@0.5:0.95 by 3.7%, and increases FPS by 4%. The optimized algorithm is suitable for environments with limited hardware resources and provides an efficient solution for crop disease detection.
Funding Information: National Natural Science Foundation of China;
Author Keywords: smart agriculture;target detection;lightweight networks;crop diseases
IEEE Terms: Deformable models;Smart agriculture;Accuracy;Target recognition;Crops;Object detection;Feature extraction;Hardware;Optimization;Diseases
